column40: The most rewarding for me was delivering a dashboard that will be a great tool for them to both assess impact and assist with grant proposals. The client was very impressed and happy with the final product and that was extremely rewarding for all.
column41: For me and I think the rest of the team, the most difficult and frustrating part of the project was our Account Director (AD). I went into this project as Analytics Consultant and a couple of months in, I took on the project manager role as well after one of our teammates had to quit the project. As project manager, I felt that our AD micromanaged my duties and didn't allow me to take full ownership of the role. She was also very unstable and would get "very nervous" at the slightest issue, which made it hard for the team to stay focused. I feel I spent too much time putting her at ease and reassuring her that things would be ok. I also felt she put a lot of pressure on the team to work at a faster pace than was necessary - from the beginning she spent a lot of time trying to have us finish ahead of schedule. At the end of the project, she told the team last minute that she would not be at the final meeting with the client because she had to travel. That meeting was later rescheduled due to weather and she told me she was traveling through the end of the month so she would not be able to attend any rescheduled meeting. So it became apparent that perhaps her motive for rushing the project was to accommodate her travel plans. Among other issues that came up throughout the project, I spent too much time managing her and answering questions that she could easily locate if she referred to emails or project materials - so while I felt the project timeline was very appropriate to accommodate people with varied schedules, she made me feel at times overwhelmed and rushed to complete tasks.
column47: The experience, with the exception of our AD, was great and very rewarding. I enjoyed working with the rest of the team and felt I was able to both contribute to and learn from the project. I will definitely volunteer again.

column47: I've now been on two projects where the client seemed unprepared for Taproot, meaning they were in the middle of a name change when they were having a logo or brochure designed so the end product only becomes a placeholder. I've heard other volunteers with similar experiences. It is very frustrating to spend so much time and effort on a project that the client either never uses or treats as a temporary fix. I'm wondering if there's some way for Taproot to vet the clients better before assigning grants by making sure they aren't contemplating a major change within their organization and thereby interrupting the working process or timeline. The client needs to be committed to the project and have key pieces in place to make the project happen, such as already having funds allocated, if needed or having a committee in place to make decisions  before a Taproot team is brought on board.

column47: It was helpful that Taproot had all the templates. I actually changed some of the templates and branded them more so the client could recognize taproot more.    It would have been helpful if the team was able to meet each other prior to agreeing to work on the project at taproot's office or somewhere like that. My team was professional but there were lots of reasons why I would have not chosen this project if I had known some of the personalities of who I was working with.    Taproot should provide some resources as well. There are things like conference phone lines and conference rooms that we could have meet at to work on projects together which would have streamlined some things. Rather than just meeting at a Starbucks or other coffee shop.   Also something for document share between consultants. Such as a google drive or cloud share where consultants are trained to upload and share documents would be beneficial for remote team work such as this.

column41: I found the project manager difficult to work with. He was often dismissive of other viewpoints, and defensive when confronted with any disagreements or alternative views.
column42: Mindy Schleger, who was originally on the project, and I got along well and I found her expertise helpful and interesting.
column43: Peter Smith, who I found to be exceptionally difficult to work with.
column46: Having had to very different experiences, i would recommend making sure to get a good feel on the project team before wholly embarking on a project. So, a very hearty yes, but with reservations.
column47: Being generous here, I couldnt help but wonder if it was the project manager's personal connection to the nonprofit that made it so difficult to work well on this project. He had volunteered for the organization in the past, was very personally invested in their mission and goals (and his interpretation of them), and through the course of this project, decided to join one of the organization's major planning committees. It made it very difficult to objectively do anything regarding the work of the organization, as it was all filtered through his view of its capabilities and his sense of what the priorities should be. He also had his own view of what the project should do - focusing very much on "strategic questions" for the organization, but (and again, perhaps because of his personal investment in the organization?), I felt like he was putting the cart before the horse, with an already-established answer for what the solutions should be, while the rest of the team was trying to better account for what the questions and problems were. I didnt notice this on my prior project, that seemed to map out on the blueprint more, and didnt have such a strong focus on self-identified strategic questions. Perhaps this could be avoided through better project management, but from an institutional standpoint, it may be beneficial if Taproot tried to avoid such direct personal involvement by its project managers in the nonprofits for which they're overseeing projects.

column41: Having one member who was, from the onset, was abrasive, disruptive, and unprofessional in both deliverables and personal conduct towards me, before the entire team.  Considering this is volunteer work and in which I held 2 roles (PM + lead strategy consultant), this made me question the screening process that Taproot takes in its volunteer applicants and level-setting expectations of individual conduct and teamwork.      It was also frustrating that there was scope creep which seemed to be brought on by someone from the client's side, who was not involved with the Taproot project from the onset or the application grant, it seems.  We lost momentum half-way through the project and needed some time to get folks all on the same page again and working towards an end-result which would be fruitful for the client and also manageable for our team's capacity and timeline.
column42: Elaine Zinngrabe, Chris Orenchuk, Julia Zukowski, John Obligato
column47: There should be more involvement with the Taproot associates with the actual volunteers - I felt rather disengaged in the entire process and it would have been nice to actually have some face-time a couple of times during the duration of our 7-month long engagement, which was something echoed by a couple of members on the team.    I think that there also needs to be more reinforcement by Taproot of the 'ground rules' at the new volunteer orientation session + at the start of each engagement.  Generally speaking, most people are good natured, amicable, and united in their interest to serve the community.  However, as it is Chicago, we have individuals who have relocated from different parts of the globe with different expectations on communication, feedback / analysis, and professional conduct.  While I have international experience, I don't think anyone could have predicted or expected such behavior as I was dealt by one Taproot member.  In addition to ignoring emails, which had action items and direct questions for her, she also missed meetings and/or arrived 20 minutes late.  She then thought it was appropriate to yell at / attempt to humiliate me before the team, indicating that I hadn't provided certain key information -- when in fact, they were and multiple times, at that.  She was not collaborative or open to any sort of editing or feedback on her interview report write-ups, which were fraught with sentence fragments, spelling errors, and unclear references - basic questions resulted in outbursts and personal attacks.  That type of is something, no volunteer signs up for and makes me rather hesitant to even sign-up for another project, despite how much great work our team (without her) achieved with AAI.

column40: CFPA does enormously important work. I have a lot of respect for the impact they have made and their efforts to improve food policy. I was proud to contribute to their cause and have already told the CFPA staff that I would like to contribute further in the future (after  a brief community service hiatus due to the upcoming birth of my child).
column41: We unfortunately had some serious problems with our team, causing a lot of stress and additional time spent dealing with behavior problems. Lee Ann, our AD, was great. We have worked together before and chose to work together again on this project. I also enjoyed interacting with Sabrina, our brand strategist, though we did have a few language issues crop up. That aside, I think she is smart, capable and pleasant to work with and may have also been impacted by the negative and difficult personalities on our team. Our copywriter and marketing manager were a different story. I regret having to say this but I recommend that Taproot reconsider having the marketing manager, Gayle Gilfillan, as a pro-bono consultant. I do not think she represents the organization well and I think her extremely negative attitude during the project toward her team, Taproot processes and the client make her a liability, as well as an unpleasant and difficult teammate. She consistently challenged me and the AD, to the point of screaming at us on the phone (more than once). She balked at committing to regular meetings. She balked at committing to her portion of the work (after agreeing to sign on and saying she understood the role). The AD wound up taking on one of her major deliverables. She constantly criticized the client in ways that were beyond constructive and instead came across as disrespectful. She complained often about Taproot processes. Toward the end, she said she no longer cared about the project (in less polite language). I became pregnant shortly after signing on and after going through my first trimester with bad morning sickness, extreme fatigue and constant battles with Gayle, considered leaving the project to protect my health. It was the last thing I wanted to do and I worked it out with my AD but I hate that I got to that point. I strongly believed in our mission and resented that Gayle made the process so difficult when it didn't need to be that way. She was so negative that the AD and I were afraid of letting her speak to the client alone and of what she might say during board training. Obviously we need to give the client constructive criticism--and we did--but her comments in team meetings about the client were over the line and disrespectful. Our copywriter was not as difficult as Gayle but she was also a problematic team member. Bri is smart and capable but she sometimes came across as immature in her approach to the project. She initially said she wanted to take a bigger role in the project and when it no longer suited her, she simply didn't fulfill her duties--leaving our brand manager in the lurch. She responded poorly to feedback, dismissing comments from the AD and I or responding in a churlish manner. We were always sensitive in giving feedback and were careful to do so in a way that was constructive and not overbearing. I have been a marketing writer and have managed creative teams so I understand the importance of respecting the writer's vision and not dictating. However, Bri didn't seem to want to hear any comments from either of us (or, at times, from the client) no matter how they were delivered. She delivered good work in the end but both the AD and I felt that she was often rude and dismissive and didn't feel it necessary to adhere to deadlines, meet team commitments or respond to emails in a timely manner. This was unfortunate as she made a great first impression and we were both excited to have her on the team. It could be that she just has some growing to do in terms of professional maturity. I realize this is a harsh assessment of some of our team members and I regret having to write it. But both Lee Ann and I felt that complete honesty was merited in this situation for the good of the Taproot organization. It's a bit uncomfortable having to deliver these types of comments in a survey as I would rather do so in a conversation. If you would like to speak more about this project, I would be happy to set up a call. On a positive note, I had a better experience with the non-profit. We had some trouble initially getting through to them regarding the fact that in discovery interviews, we heard consistently that they were challenging to work with. We wanted to deliver this message gently but felt it was important for them to know since their success is dependent on collaboration. We also had a taste of their thorniness at times. I think they all mean well though and by the end of the project, I felt they were making an effort to be more open and collaborative and a bit "softer."  I also had a great experience working with my client contact, Alexis. She is smart and dedicated and was a pleasure to work with throughout.
column47: I recommend reviewing the templates for the project as they don't all match up with the new quick start guide. This made it a bit confusing for the team. In terms of hiring pro-bono consultants, I recommend that you spend more time assessing the candidates' willingness to commit a significant amount of time and energy to projects as well as to assessing their ability to work well with others. It's great to be smart and have experience but if you don't want to put the time in or you are uncomfortable working under a peer in a volunteer situation, Taproot probably isn't a great fit. You may wind up hiring fewer consultants but they will be of higher quality. This will help the organization in providing a better overall experience for grantees as well as by ensuring that you don't lose good consultants because they've had bad experiences.

column41: I was shocked and frustrated with team members who would drop off of the project. Our account manager was excellent and very clearly let all team members know what the expectations were and people still just flaked. We had 3 marketing managers leave, one financial analyst, and one designer (after designs were presented). Ramping multiple people back on the project was extremely time consuming, and by the end I feel there was little group cohesion or excitement about the project. Everyone, including the client, just wanted to be done with it.
column46: Perhaps in another role, I would have had a better experience. I think it was too time consuming and people's lack of commitment was disappointing. I'm not sure what (if anything) Taproot can do to fix that, but I was shocked that others felt okay just dropping off the project.
column47: The client was stressed and irritated by the project dragging on and people dropping off. I personally had several in-person meetings, about 10 phone calls, and sometimes daily emails with the client. At times she was rude in her communications, and it was not enjoyable for me to be a part of it. I was tired of training multiple team members, tired of picking up slack where others dropped off, and tired of the constant emails from the client. I was so excited to start this project, but by the end I just couldn't wait for it to be over. I applied to work for this organization years ago, and was excited to work with them. In the end, I felt that bridges were burned and they thought I was unprofessional. But I'm not sure what else I could have done. Except for one 1-week vacation over the year, I never let 24 hours go by without returning an email or phone call. The last communication I got from the client was one of annoyance, and the team just fizzled out. I wish that my first experience with Taproot would have been better because I'm not sure I would participate on a project again.

column41: There were 4 frustrating parts to the project.    1. The project manager did not follow the project blueprint:  Initially, a requirements brief was not submitted; Client signatures were not procured at key milestones;  The project manager frequently followed a process that was quite different from the process outlined in the blueprint. This caused significant delays and required additional time from myself and other team members.    2. The client (executive director) did not follow the blueprint, and did not seem familiar with the service grant. For example she expected focus groups, even though they are clearly identified as out of scope in the grant.     3. On more than one occasion, the executive director changed her mind after providing approval/direction for a particular step in the process.    4. The executive director would not allow a discussion after the draft designs were presented.
column47: This was my second taproot project were the project manager did not follow the taproot blueprint.

column47: Two things. 1) Most web projects now include a content strategist, whose role is different from a writer. I ended up doing both on this project, but think it would be helpful if the role of content strategist was formalized as part of the Taproot project. Second, and related, is that most organizations have someone who writes and who is asked to do the writing for the project, under the supervision/editing of the Taproot person. This can prove difficult if the person's skills are not adequate or appropriate for webwriting, or for content strategy (which usually falls to the content person).

column41: The most frustrating part of the project for the team was clearly a very difficult difference of opinion that developed late in the project. The client asked for a number of changes to the near-final brochure that violated the agreement from the Requirements Brief. The team and our designer in particular were strongly opposed to these changes and I generally had to agree with them. While the changes did not affect my contribution to the piece (the content) I think the dispute greatly diminished my team's satisfaction with the project. The client also made some comments that were (perhaps unintentionally) mildly rude and dismissive of the team's work.
column47: This was my fourth project (one brochure, one annual report, two website) and I have seen a pretty consistently recurring problem - the difficulty of impressing upon the client the obligation created at the Requirements Brief stage. To varying degrees, clients always seem to request changes at later stages that to some degree go against what was agreed upon earlier. This was a minor issue in my last three projects and a bigger issue in this one. I don't know if that's just my anecdotal experience or reflected in other projects, but it's the biggest challenge my teams have faced - clients simply don't say all that's on their minds (or can't express it clearly) until they have a draft in front of them.

column47: The templates and example should be updated including just the basic formatting. The formation of this committee was recommended by the prior Taproot HR Capacity consultants.    Finally, it was inspiring to work with Nina Sinclair-Burns and our HR consultants.  I was able to learn a great deal from them, as I provided guidance and managed the project.  I am proud of what we accomplished, despite confusing directives and life challenges within our group.
column41: I was able to discuss many of my frustrations with Mini Datta, in my "lessons learned" feedback to her.  The project, overall, was very confusing and time consuming (due to confusion).  It is my understanding that this project had a different structure than previous projects, which I assume contributed to some confusing directives as we proceeded in the project.  I feel the following would have been helpful:  1)  Contractual information that clearly identified the client (Family Rescue or Chicago Battered Women's Network), and outlined scopes of services needed and/or expected.  2) An orientation process for the pro bono team, that is tailored to the nuances of the project.  3)  Technical assistance methods that quickly identified and addressed special project needs based on a "pilot" project structure.

column47: As mentioned to the Program Manager, for Salesforce projects, there needs to be an assessment of apps on the App Exchange before the service grant is approved, and include any potential apps in the scope of the project. Then the project team can be gathered based on knowledge/experience of the app, as well as on Salesforce. And even if that is not possible, the team will be aware of the possibility of including a third-part app in the implementation.

column40: The most rewarding part for me was learning the client stories and how much they've helped low income Los Angelenos. I can't stress enough that NLSLA is an amazing organization - they are making real change in our communities and even in national legislation! It was beneficial getting to know what they wanted to convey with their annual report and who they were trying to target.
column41: The most frustrating part of the project is how long it took to actually complete the annual report and the fact that people kept dropping out due to their frustrations with the process, etc. It was hard gathering all of the details without a marketing person to help guide me (the graphic designer) and the copywriter. Even though we (graphic designer & copywriter) were the newest members of the team, we joined a year after the project had already been in progress, her and I just ended up writing our own layout and just submitting what we thought the annual report should look/flow like - without having much background. It was frustrating to me that the marketing and project managers didn't take initiative or leadership to get the annual report completed in time - but looking back now, it may have worked for the best since I was able to just do my part and get things done as best I could. It was a turn off experiencing a project that took almost 2 years to complete... I worked on a different taproot project, while I was on this project (also an annual report) that took 3 months to complete and ran so smoothly because everyone had equal responsibilities and all members were just as invested as the others. The project manager on that project was awesome about keeping the client accountable and on time with giving us the information we needed - it was a great show of leadership. Experiencing both a really great project and a frustrating one like this one - leaves me a bit hesitant to work on another pro-bono project.
column46: I would, but with a warning that not all project experiences are equal...
column47: I would appreciate if my information and comments are kept confidential. Please contact me if you need further information. Lluvia@lluviaarras.com

column40: 1. Despite setbacks and occasional apathy, it was great to work with a fun bunch of qualified, professional team-members  2. Seeing the final deliverable evolve into a worthwhile document.
column41: 1. As project manager, I insisted numerous times on revisiting the project timeline - to gauge (a) team-member availability and time commitments to the project and (b) time needs for task completion, to make the milestones more realistic, but was met with apathy and a lack of mobilization and commitment on this subject every time. As a result, the timeline in the Taproot system, unfortunately, contained unrealistic, unrealizable dates for the milestones, even when it was occasionally updated.  2. The client had virtually no involvement. They sat back and waited for us to perform.  3. There were times in which the client was slow to respond to requests or provide feedback, which then delayed the project; and then they commented that they had expected to receive the deliverable sooner. Cumulatively, I estimate that client delays accounts for about 5-7 weeks of delay over the life of the project.  4. It took a long time for the team to develop cohesion, only for the team to fall apart with 2 departures. We only found one viable replacement; As a result, the additional burden of a team-member's workload had to be shared on the remaining team members. Recruitment of a new team member accounts for about 2-4 weeks of delay.

column41: I think we had some misunderstandings of what they thought we could do deliver and what we did deliver.  I agreed to be the performance management analyst, but I am a generalist with limited experience in PM. I made it very clear to the project manager the limitations I was bringing to the position and that I would need help.  He said I would get help.  When it came time to create a new pm system, I felt like I was in over my head and asked for help.  I didn't really get it.  I did my best with my limited experience.  It was not what the client wanted.  In the end, I think they got what they really needed which was how to coach their employees to produce more, vs creating a review that would make them meet their goals.  Our team fell apart at the end and we did not have a final meeting with the client as a team.  The project manager did the final pieces of the work.  I felt like there was disappointment with my work.  That said, when I asked for help, no one stepped up to the plate.  I was in over my head.  I did my best.

column41: Getting to/from meetings in downtown Chicago was a pain.  I signed up for the north side of the city and while the client was located there, most of the team wasn't.  This meant lots of pricy parking and travel during rush hour.  Not fun or convenient.  With regard to the project itself, it felt like once we were cast into our roles, there was a hierarchy that we never got past.  Despite the fact I had direct experience with both non-profits and consulting, it still felt like I was low man on the totem pole because of the title I was assigned to.  Just didn't feel very team like to me - felt just like an entry-level job which I am years beyond!  Don't get me wrong, there was definitely collaboration and relative harmony, it just wasn't exactly what I was expected for a volunteer type role.
column46: Unfortunately, I think I'd say no (considering the volume of work and demands on time).
column47: I love Taproot's blueprints as tools.  Very helpful.  The negative side of that was that some of my teammates didn't seem to think we could deviate in the slightest from this and that I found frustrating.  I think we need to be flexible and adjust accordingly where necessary.  Not saying to go rogue, but where it makes sense, add, delete, or rearrange.      All in all, Taproot is a fabulous concept.  I'm proud of the work accomplished and I know it will be helpful to the JASC.  I just think based on my personal experience, I didn't love the environment enough to devote that much time and energy to another project.  Perhaps more team "bonding" (i.e. an informal get together, not just project launch rolled into one meeting) before project starts so it's not all business from the get go??

column41: The Taproot team kept changing, from the very beginning. We got off to a slow start because the Project Manager was never really part of the project. Right before the kick-off meeting, another team member, the original Strategy Consultant, left the team. And before the final phase of the project, the team member who came in last to replace the original Strategy Consultant also left the team. In the end there was only a core team of 3 people including the Account Director.
column47: Given the changes in the team, there should be some formal commitment a team member makes when accepting a project. Upon consideration of the grant, timeline, and estimated work time, it should be something signed/clicked to affirm commitment to the team and grant. Then, if things come up, which are inevitable, it would give second thought to letting down the Taproot team and non-profit.

column41: Both myself, my account director, our copywriter, graphic designer and the original project manager were all new to our role on this Taproot project, so there was a bit of a "hit the ground running" learning curve. Our project manager left the project early and was never replaced, so our account director took on her role--a mistake.  Then our graphic designer had attitude issues and was finally removed, but not replaced, and our account director took on that role as well. Although I commend him for taking on so much, we should have replaced those roles early on with new people, as the frustrations of the project started to weigh on him, heavily.  Having stated that, there was a great deal of teeth pulling trying to get information from the client, yet I expected them to have difficulty in this area, as this was the reason we were enlisted to help. It's nothing that I haven't dealt with before, nor anything I wasn't expecting (as frustrating as it was dealing with our client) but our account director seemed to disagree, and found the client to be quite disorganized and absentminded, to the point of wanting to end the project. I'd like to think that better management decisions throughout would have led to a better working relationship between client and team, and an overall smoother better end result.

column42: Amy McMillan, Ralph Sanchez, Xavier Armanno, Amy Stockli, Ari Krzyzek
column47: Yes and yes. We need to improve training for both the pro bono consultants and client in regards to project management. The blue prints template are more of a hindrance then useful. Additional training either through prerecorded youtube video, webinar, face to face training or all the above, would drastically help reduce the resistance and increase the success of our project. After two projects, one of the challenges that we experiences repeated again was no single tool to manage the project tasks and documents. Using emails just became unmanageable, but thankfully our Acct Mgr (Ralph) insisted we use DropBox which helped but we still had challenges when we had to deal with collaboration work on documentation and presentations. I plan to continue volunteering bc Taproot is incredible services to the Chicago area and I would love to help Taproot make the improvements I suggested. Pro bono of course! :)

column41: In terms of the client, I'm not sure they were ready for this project.  Their strategic plan was quite aspirational, which made it hard to narrow down the goals.  I am not sure that the Exec Dir is ready to have a disciplined approach to programs (i.e., does this opportunity fit with our long term goals).  On the other hard, I do think they got a lot of value from looking at their three year plan and organization with the perspective of measurable goals and outcomes.

column41: - This project would really have benefited from an experienced information architect being included on the team  - Key individuals from the client were not available for long periods; this particularly impacted content preparation, which affected design and development work in turn  - The Taproot templates and guidelines for a Website II project are based on a 6-month timeline.  I was surprised when our Taproot program manager commented that our project was one of Taproot's fastest website projects, and I feel I would not have pushed the pace as hard if the templates were more in synch with Taproot's experience of other projects.
column47: - I believe the Account Lead role should be clarified under the Taproot model  - I would also recommend that all team members be given a short refresher training course at the start of every new project on the Taproot methodology for that project type  - In resourcing a Taproot project team, the Account Lead (and project manager if involved in resourcing) should consider a candidate's relevant experience; for example, an individual may be a very experienced graphic designer but may have limited experience in website design

column41: Although the Account Director and Project Manager were great and worked hard to make the project a success, the three other members (besides myself) were unreliable and/or insufficiently skilled.  The Marketing Manager quit in the first month, and I took on that role, along with Content Manager. The web developer was not up to speed on the technology, complained incessantly about trivial matters, and ultimately had to be taken off of the project.  The designer, while skilled and professional, basically ended up "phoning it in" and just stopped returning calls or answering questions after he felt he had submitted adequate designs. The whole thing was extremely frustrating to the three of us who were left, but we did manage to deliver an awesome product.
column43: Michael Peterson, Sagar Rami, Stephanie Won
column47: I'm not sure how expectations are transmitted to the team, but perhaps there is a better way of making sure people understand their commitments and roles when they undertake a project.  At first, our Account Director was pretty hands-off, and it would have been better if she had played a more central role from the beginning. She ended up doing virtually all of the development and much of the design work on the website. Had she not had the skills to step in and do the work, the project would have been a total disaster. The graphic designer was unwilling to do more than submit a few basic designs, and then went AWOL.  It was unclear whose responsibility it was to produce the site architecture, so I did it myself.  On previous Taproot website projects, we developed the structure as a team, and that worked very well.  On the VERY bright side, the client was wonderful, extremely easy to work with, very appreciative, and above all, very patient with our slow progress.  I think we delivered a very nice product, which I am proud of, but at one point the AD told the client, "If I were you and had hired us to do this project, I would have fired us long ago!"

column40: Knowing that what we were doing was valued and needed by the client.  Testing my skills in the workplace after taking leave to have my child.  Working with and learning from my team mates.

Taproot did not seem to provide much assistance to the program director to find a new copywriter, for example they could have used the partnership they have with LinkedIn to find someone, but they didn't.

column41: My team never really coalesced, due to the account manager and project managers. Both had good intentions, but delayed taking action when the graphics person was clearly inadequate and uncooperative (we had to bring in a nonTaproot designer to save the day). Two or three of us did all the work: the photographer was inert and uninspired, the acct person long winded, repetitive (the weekly calls could be frustrating), and officious, which wasn't necessary. The three of us were professional consultants and did not need that level of oversight. The project manager became more decisive at the end, but we still lost at least a month waiting for her to drop the graphics person; we could have delivered the piece on time had we acted sooner, which two of us advocated several times.

column47: This was my second Taproot project and found it paled in comparison to the first.  The Taproot materials were nearly as good for this brochure project (the blueprint was unnecessarily long and detailed given the relatively straightforward nature of a brochure project).  I suggest these materials could use a revamp with an eye to providing more strategic direction and guidelines and fewer in-the-weeds details.    Also, my team was far less professional on this second project. Our first graphic designer showed up to the kickoff meeting with the client in shorts and a ripped tshirt. Our project manager seemed unfamiliar with even the basics of scheduling or dealing with a client and shifting deadlines.  And, our director provided little leadership in the beginning.  His input on the brochure content and design was good, but his leadership skills were not.

column41: Terrible Account Director - you should make sure to align the skills and experience of the account director by subject area/discipline such as finance/marketing better. Instead it leads to conflicts and resolutions that could be avoided

column47: Input previously provided to Trevor Kaul:    I have been doing my best to integrate my experience with Taproot and the TLC Project in an effort to communicate to you in a way that might be of value.  There have been a variety of aspects of that experience from the very positive to the negative, so it is not easy to come up with a consistent theme in the provision of input to you.  I greatly appreciated your own understanding of my upset and concerns when you entered a difficult situation after Kandaces abrupt departure.  I could have been more understanding of your own situation at that point.  The way you reacted made me feel better about Taproot and especially your own role and our ability to communicate with each other.    I will provide some commentary related to my experiences and areas that Taproot might consider as it moves forward.        COMMENTARY    Initial Reactions    My initial reactions and involvement with Taproot were quite positive.  I was impressed with Kandace and the two initial meetings, including training related to the Taproot process.  I was impressed with the structured information about the various programs, as long as they were suggestions rather than requirements.  Additionally, I was fortunate to be assigned to the TLC project, the first one in which I had expressed interest.    Recruitment for the Project    One of my most difficult experiences was recruiting for the TLC Project.  Although there were a large number of candidates listed, few were actually available, interested, or qualified.  Half the people that I contacted did not have the courtesy to respond that they were neither available nor interested.  Of the remainder, some who responded were not available at the time.  The first person that I talked to as a potential project manager indicated a need to be appointed to the position prior to even meeting with me in person.  Regretfully, I agreed.  After meeting her and introducing her to TLC leadership, we mutually decided it would be better for her not to continue.      Fortunately, I subsequently found two strong candidates in Erica Caplan and Sara Yang.  Although I believed that the three of us (or even two of us) could effectively complete the project, I wanted to be a compliant Account Director and have the five team members that Taproot suggests for a project of this type.  I continued to work at identifying additional team members.  I found two others who were interested in working on the project but expressed some concerns about their time limitations.  I acknowledged such restrictions and identified a modest role for them to play.  For one, I sent some materials for her to review and provide feedback.  She never even followed up with any feedback.   For another, I asked for a time for us to talk about specifics and did not hear from her for three weeks.  At that time she indicated that she had taken a job and did not have much time for any project work.  I removed both of these people from the project team.    In summary, a huge amount of time was wasted in recruitment efforts, and many of these individuals were neither available nor interested in serving as pro bono consultants.    Conduct of the Project    The best part of my experience was the actual conduct of the project.  The two team members were exceptional.  Although quite busy, they worked hard and efficiently to produce a strong product and outcome.  Additionally, the two TLC leaders (Executive Director and Human Resources Lead) were also exceptional in the involvement and support they offered to the project.  I feel that the five of us worked very well together in a manner that compared to some of the best consulting projects with which I have been involved.    Monitoring of the Project by Taproot    There were some problems for me with Taproots monitoring of the project.  Automatically generated requests for input on a weekly basis waste time and are disrespectful to the Account Directors.  I did discuss these concerns with Kandace and yourself, and both of you made some accommodations.    It would seem that shortly after a project begins that you might want to check with the organization to see how it perceives the work of the pro bono consultants.  Such input could then determine the extent of your need for oversight and review of the consultants.  Additionally, arrangements can be made with each Account Director regarding the timing, frequency and nature of follow-up.  I had not been so micro-managed this closely since I had been in graduate school and just beginning consulting work.  I did my best to shield the project manager from having to deal with the requests.  I typically shared with her my responses to these requests, and she was amazed at the level of inquiry.        The Closing Call    The closing conference call was a little strange.  Mini conducted the call in a reasonable manner to collect information that was hopefully useful for her.  However, as a conference call in which Kate and Max were apparently to participate, other than stating that they were present at the beginning of the call, there was not another word that came from either of them (not even a good-bye at the end).  I even made a positive comment about Max and his background during the conversation with Mini, partly to see if he was still there (or awake), but there was no response.  This is hardly a big deal, but I doubt that I am the only one who would perceive this type of conference call behavior as a bit strange and inappropriate.       AREAS FOR CONSIDERATION    Personnel Management    The true mettle of an organization is represented by the manner in which it deals with its employees.  I was particularly distressed about Kandaces departure, and especially about the manner in which it occurred.  I had been impressed with Kandace in my involvement and interactions with her.  When we had differences of opinion, we were able to discuss and satisfactorily resolve them.  Certainly, there may have been areas in which she performed poorly or even that she did not belong in her position.  The manner of her dismissal, however, seems inappropriate unless she was stealing from the organization or abusing its employees.  Additionally, it had been noted to me that this type of dismissal process is not atypical for Taproot.  Subsequently, I understand that Beth was also dismissed.  It is difficult to understand how an organization in the business of providing pro bono consulting support to others has a culture of managing its own personnel in such a negative manner.    Nature of Consultants    I have concerns about the consultants that are presented as being available for the pro bono projects.  It is not clear whether they are truly available or whether their background has been adequately assessed.  Hardly any of the potential consultants that I reviewed had previously been involved in any Taproot project, and the general lack of responsiveness of a good number seemed to demonstrate little commitment to Taproots work.  Additionally, it seemed that a significant number of those on the list were in job transition and were not necessarily committed to pro bono consulting work.  In my previous pro bono consulting activities, other consultants with whom I was involved had a different profile than most of those that I encountered in my recruitment efforts for the Taproot project.  They were highly experienced professionals from corporate and consulting settings who had a strong commitment to do work with the non-profit sector.  Although some of the Taproot consultants might fit that profile, it might be possible to recruit a higher proportion of individuals with such background and commitment.     Efficiency    Highly qualified individuals desiring to serve as pro bono consultants need to be extremely efficient in the utilization of their time.  For Taproot to recruit and utilize such highly qualified consultants, it will need to be more efficient in dealing with them, respect their capabilities, and allow them to use the time that they contribute in the most effective manner.  Clearly, the management and oversight of Taproot personnel would need to be modified.      It is hard to understand why it is necessary for five individuals to typically comprise a Taproot pro bono consulting team.  Especially with the time constraints, it can be difficult to manage a team of that size, and the work that needs to be done does not seem to necessitate such a number of personnel.  Even our team of three was more than ample for the TLC project, and it could have easily been done with any two of us.  I needlessly spent a significant amount of time in the recruitment process.      I am not sure of the benefit of listing a large number of consultants who are not interested or committed to truly to engaging in pro bono work or to overstaffing projects with more individuals than is necessary to efficiently complete the work.  There may be alternatives that would allow you to recruit more qualified and committed consultants and provide a higher level of pro bono support to the non-profits in the communities that you serve.      CONCLUSION    It is important to qualify my comments and observations as coming from an individual who has a limited vantage point.  I feel comfortable in sharing this input with you as you are open-minded and can also share alternative perspectives given your broader knowledge about the Washington Office and Taproot.    I hope that some of this input is of value to you.  If you would like to follow-up, I would be glad to do so either by telephone or in person.    I view my Taproot and TLC experience as being very valuable.  I remain available to continue to support TLC and will expand my involvement in pro bono work.  Such work has been very enjoyable and provides an opportunity to make contributions in areas that are very important to me.  It has brought me back to my early days in Community Psychology.    Again, thank you for your support and involvement, and I look forward to keeping in touch.

In future, I would recommend that the full Taproot team and full Client team have a face-to-face meeting very early.  That would serve to interactively and dynamically clarify and focus the scope of the project at an early phase when the client is most enthusiastic about telling their story and when there is no pressure on the Taproot team to deliver anything (other than to just show up).      Moreover, it would help to solidify the Taproot team members; and team member roles would naturally emerge during the course of the meeting.

column41: 1. Account director had to leave at the beginning of the project. 2. Project manager was assigned to act on this role too, but was not doing a good job at managing the project (dates, info, status, calls). 3 Project manager pushed for some solutions that might not have been the best option for the client.  4.  Skills of the IT person were not matching the project and did not participate much to the project, getting the other team members to cover his part. 5.  Final meetings and discussion were done without 2 members (including myself) being around (vacations) whereas the travel dates had been shared with the project manager a while back. I understand the constraint of timeline but a few days wait would have probably allowed the whole group to meet and present final project to clients. Overall, the management of the project impacted my motivation in being involved.

column40: Working with the non-profit people, and the most team members
column41: The account director suggested many ideas which were out of scope.  In our first group meeting with the client, he promised that we would develop fundraising scripts for board members to use.  Another time he assigned me to do their 2013 detail budget for the client.  I don't think this would have been desired by the client, nor helpful.  Frequently he discussed the benefit of changing their accounting methodology from an accrual basis to a cash basis, which was well out of our scope and expertise.
column42: Nicole Chen, Carol Baker, Will Ross

column40: It was great to see how passionate Ensemble Espanol is about what they do.  We were able to remove a few road blocks from a financial reporting standpoint that hopefully will allow the group to move forward with funding and expansion of their organization.
column41: Understanding the challenges that Ensemble Espanol was facing was probably the most challenging aspect of the projec.

column40: The client seemed to have a number of 'aha' moments. Good for me to see how non profits work - the difference between non profit and profit orgs.
column41: We had one Taproot team member who had a very assertive communication style - good points but damaging delivery among the internal team and shared confidential info with the client leaders. She made it a sometimes not-so-fun project to be on. Templates are very complete but results in a lot of repetition (i.e., the powerpoints). Eventually we stopped using them. As project manager and not having picked the team myself (hence not confident in the consultant's skillset initially) and then learning that the client had printed all docs and was following them.... I erred on the side of caution and followed everything completely at the onset. Taproot should either revisit the docs or state boldly and clearly that they are just for reference. I suggest revisiting or stating which ones are mandatory since as a 'professional' org, you may want to  have some consistency across the engagements. Taproot and whomever chooses the team needs to properly screen the team members to ensure they have time and flexibility to meet - it was hard for our group to meet in person but when we did, we did really good work. Suggest some kind of a central spot on the taproot site to share interview notes, docs, etc. We had lots of emails and no one place to store everything so that we could read everything and get a similar 'complete' picture of the client (during the analysis phase).  Lastly, we had a lovely celebration dinner with just our taproot team after the project ended - suggest we do this at the onset to build relationships (get to 'performing') more quickly.
column47: The internal team went through the typical team building phases (to get to a point where we were functioning really well) and spent a lot of time learning about the client. Seems like a waste of effort to have provided the client with only an assessment and a couple of quick hits. We did take on additional work but would recommend a Part 2 where the team sees some near term projects through.

column40: Providing a product that the staff and board appeared to be very happy with.
column41: Lack of strong leadership, lack of momentum to keep the project moving. Several new members on the team who were unfamiliar with the Taproot process -- I don't believe the received the guidance they needed to understand what was expected of them. These projects always require a lot of work, but for some reason, this one seemed to take more work than might have been necessary.

I would have been okay with the PM taking more leadership over some of the lesser assignments rather than checking in with us on direction.  Also disagreed on scope question, we stayed within scope but the client couldn't keep to schedule so pushed us over the time frame.

That turned the project in to work and took away one of the most satisfying parts of being on a Taproot project (getting to work with likeminded individuals).  The AD also  gave confusing direction and, in general, created a lot more work than was necessary to get the job done.
column47: Our project manager did not mediate well between the AD and the copywriter or the AD and the marketing manager (me).  Project Manager did an excellent job at keeping a calendar, but we really needed someone to help manage up.

I also felt that the AD, a wonderful person, was nonetheless less than flexible in areas where he needed to be, and didn't manage the client or PM well enough.
column47: I found the experience to be both rewarding and difficult. Yet I also felt we did great work together and delivered something of high value and, as tired as I was by the end, I would do it again. I'm happy to discuss my feedback in detail in a meeting.

column41: Our account director was tough to work with. She was often unprofessional, lacked clear vision and made parts of the process difficult. Although dedicated to the cause, her leadership style was often caustic. She talked about other team members behind their backs, advised to plagiarize (then denied it when confronted) and spoke rudely on more than one occasion. She had positive attributes, but the negatives were quite unpleasant. If she were not on the team, the entire project would have been a joy.
column47: My first experience w/ the Taproot Everyone Reading team was terrific. This one was disappointing -- not in the Taproot spirit at all. I also want to recommend Debbie Atuk for future AE roles -- she has what you're looking for, plus some.

column47: This is the second Taproot project I've worked on & both times the photography as been an after thought once the project got kicked off. It would be great if Account Directors planned for photography earlier in the process.

column40: Collaboration with the client team. They are very enthusiastic about their mission and were great to know.
column41: In general, the marketing manager role has the potential to be frustrating. The upfront direction-setting is valuable and necessary, but the work output and responsibilities of that role diminish significantly after the first month of a project.   Most aspects of the marketing manager role translate well to a more hands-on account director who would not handle the day-to-day responsibility of project management, but would serve to understand the client intensively and uphold the project vision. Maybe there's a way to reshuffle some responsibilities or reimagine roles?

column21: Hudson Link for Higher Education in Prison
column40: This was a really special project, I think, where all the key factors just aligned really well. We had a great nonprofit with a POC who was a) interested and invested in what Taproot was doing, b) willing to trust us and let us do our job, and c) responsive and prompt for the most part. In many ways we had an ideal relationship with the client, and we were able to learn a great deal about their mission, goals, pain points, etc because they were so willing to work with us. We were treated like family, and I think a large part of that is the magic of this particular nonprofit and their ethos. I definitely developed a deep personal and emotional investment in the nonprofit and its associated community throughout the six months of engagement, and that was one of the key things I was seeking in joining Taproot in the first place.
column41: The nature of my role in the project was fairly limiting, and I don't think it was necessarily the right role for me. While I do work with financial analysis as a consultant in the financial services industry, I am not an accountant, and it's not the type of work I prefer. My real strength is in project management and strategy consulting - I work with clients every day and I think I could successfully take on a more significant role. I will say that the Account Director and Project Manager did a great job trying to find ways to expand my role by seeking my support on other things - mainly interviews and QC of deliverables - and I was always included in the client meetings. While that worked for this engagement, I think I might be better utilized in other, deeper capacities - and I'd appreciate the opportunity to discuss that possibility with Taproot at some point.

column47: Thanks so much for the opportunity - it was an amazing first project and I hope it's the first of many to come.

column40: - Delivering all commitments 20-21 weeks after the kickoff  - All team members were good at voicing concerns or frustrations, which allowed us to process through them as a team  - The client's praise at the end of the project was affirming and made me remember why I volunteered in the first place
column41: - Arranging meeting times is never a picnic  - It was difficult keeping the momentum after we lost a resource mid-project  - I suppose I could have done without correcting the Taproot logo on my blueprint and client-facing material
column42: Steve Schack, Lydia Yao, Didier Sylvain
column47: - Taproot branding in the blueprints and project collateral (e.g. presentation files) is inconsistent with the website.  Someone really ought to tidy that up!   - If resource attrition/turnover is a regular occurrence, it might make sense to have volunteers in some middle status (e.g. rather than active vs. on the bench).  Having access to a free resource in a pinch would be an option for managing this ever-present risk.  - I am a PMP and wonder if Taproot is tapping into the bustling PMI community in NYC for highly capable resources.  Not that I am looking to make finding a pro bono gig more difficult for myself, but I am happy to help assist in this regard and I am sure you can lure them with promises of Professional Development Units (PDUs).

column47: My only hesitation in signing up again in the near future is the substantial challenge I encountered managing the team. I spent many sleepless nights and many anguished days wondering how we would get pieces of work delivered on time when a team member did not do his or her part.  By the end I was emotionally spent and not anxious to sign up again anytime soon.  All the team members were bright, strong people in their own right, but not all wanted to commit to the others to do their parts as expected.  My frustrations only have to do with managing the team and getting quality work delivered on time.  Relating to the client was a piece of cake.

This is a serious problem and could lead to the development of communication pieces that are not what the client needs.  Taproot suggested that we have a team of 7 -- that was way too many people.  The copy writer for our team had no idea how to provide timely and appropriate work and was very rude to the client.  The client did not provide timely or well thought out responses to our drafts.  This caused our team to go through far too many rewrites.

column40: *We delivered a product that should be highly actionable for the client.   *I enjoyed the opportunity to use my skills in a different vein. *Some (see below) of my team members were great to work with and I enjoyed the interchange with them.
column41: *The timing of this project for our client wasn't optimal.  They had a couple of major events in the Spring, which impacted their focus and availability.  While we brought the project in on time, it required a crunch at the end to get it done. *I was not involved in the team selection.  From the beginning, it was evident that one of our team members was going to be difficult to work with. Dealing with her drew a lot of energy from the team and our efforts. *This was my first project.  Taproot needs to provide project manager training to its pm's.  The blueprint is great, but overwhelming. Training to break it down in advance of one's first project is critical. *The templates are great, but the color printing is outrageously expensive and bad for the environment.  Is there another option? *Better communication about changes would be great.  For example, the templates changed mid-way through our project.  While we still had access to the old ones, an email to project managers about the upcoming change would have been appreciated.
column43: Tia Skulski - should not work on another Taproot project
column47: *Consultants probably need more information about what they will be doing on the project, the timelines and time commitment prior to signing onto a project.  One of our consultants thought her role would be to refer specific potential board members; she had no idea of the type of work that would be expected of her.  Likewise, another consultant felt very insecure because this was her first project (and it was mine, too, so my only reassurance was that we would figure it out together). *I question how "ready" our client was for this project - both in terms of availability given other commitments and whether they should have done more branding work before taking on the board recruitment. *Client representatives were great once we established a rapport.

column21: Community Services for Autistic Adults and Children (CSAAC)
column40: Meeting the professionals on my project team. The ability to be creative.
column41: The CSAAC leaders we worked with made comments during one of our meetings that made me think they did not have a genuine passion for supporting individuals with autism. I got the impression they did not enjoy working with individuals with autism and perhaps regretted that aspect of their jobs. Whether they were merely "blowing off steam" or being flippant, I had a hard time feeling enthusiastic about our project after that point. I felt that their comments were unprofessional and dismissive of the actual needs of individuals with autism.  Also, I felt that our marketing manager's enthusiasm for working with CSAAC sometimes precluded others from providing input into the project. She often seemed hesitant to accept others' ideas and insights, sometimes referencing one-on-one conversations she had arranged with the client. To my knowledge, she did not invite other team members to these calls, even though their discussions involved important details on the project.
column47: I was extremely disappointed in CSAAC's apparent attitude toward their mission. As a pro bono professional, I draw my energy and focus from the client's passion for what they do; so it's difficult to stay engaged when the client does not appear to stand behind their organization. For this reason, I would not volunteer for another service grant to CSAAC. I would be happy to discuss this with a Taproot representative if needed.

column40: The client was BEYOND grateful for the work we've done.  The CEO hugged me at the end of the project.  That was amazing.
column41: We seemed to get very bogged down in the details of preliminary items that would never get to the client.  We spent so much time on revisions to the formatting of our our interview questions, for instance, that by the time we got to the point of writing key messages and strategy, there was a lot of burn out.
column47: I'm not sure Edsel was the right person to lead the team.  Please understand, I think he is a wonderful individual.  On a personal level, I think he is great.  However, I'm not sure what his marketing background is and what experience he had to draw upon.  His methodical approach, I believe, got us "caught in the weeds" several times early on in the process.  There was so much attention to the guidelines of the project, that I think the spirit of the project was sometimes left behind.

column40: The organization supports a great cause.

column46: I'm not sure - have mixed feelings about the process

column40: I liked interacting with the client. They were very easy to work with. My Taproot team was nice. Not all up for the challenge, but all nice people. Nothing personally against anyone, but some of the players seemed to have no experience in their roles, so I'm not sure things were clearly defined in advance.
column41: The length of the project. And the inability to find a programmer. Ironically, the very last guy we had was good, but by then it was too late to get everything done by our finish date. I told the client I'd be happy to assist them on my own time (apart from Taproot) to get the site looking good. Right now, it needs some serious tweakage.
column47: It was our leader Melissa's first project, so, while she dropped the ball multiple times, I'm not sure she knew what her role was. Maybe I just got lucky in the past, but I'm used to the leader stepping in when things stall. For months, no one was driving our bus, and it derailed. I'd just say to make sure the leader knows to step in sooner. And to ask questions and get help much, much sooner. Could've shaved months and months off of the length of this project, and produced a more finished outcome.

column40: Seeing how excited they were about the new logo mark.
column41: The meetings would go on forever. The client would go back on what they agreed to previously. Some teammates seemed to check-out after awhile which was frustrating.
column46: I might, but also let them know it's not really a streamlined process.
column47: I probably will not do another project through Taproot. I think that from the beginning you should set up an expectation from the beginning that though there are blueprints, it is common to diverge from them. (In the orientation it sounded like every project is run like a tight ship, when it's not.)

column40: Getting to know and interact with team members
column41: Client

column40: Making connections with an excellent team who I'd gladly work with again in the future.
column42: Kenneth Windsor, Maggie Hannon, Greg Bauman, Courtney Regan

column40: The most rewarding moments were 1) when we realized as a team that we had a strong presentation and 2) seeing the client's reaction. While the entire process was enlightening and fulfulling, ultimately our goal was to meet the client's needs and help them advance their mission. Everyone in the group had extremely high standards and I was proud that we felt good about our work and that the client felt so as well.
column41: We had an accelerated schedule in order to get photos done by the end of the school year and did not really start with the strong brand messaging that we thought the organization had already in place. That made my role particularly challenging--in the discovery phase, I was given over 20 disconnected documents to peruse in addition to the OU presentation and our interviews. I know OL was trying to be helpful but it was information overload and given our shortened schedule, this resulted in several, somewhat frustrating long days and nights. We got there at the end of the day, our initial presentation of the RB went very well and as a result, the project was a bit less hectic, but it was challenging. I have a lot of respect for the OL team and don't fault them--it's hard to do everything they do with such a small team and make time for marketing as well. However, in retrospect, I think it would have been good for the Taproot team to perhaps start with a messaging project and then do the brochure, or at least not accelerate the brochure project.
column42: I would be happy to work with anyone on the team again. I have a lot of respect for all of my team members.
column47: This was my first Taproot project and overall it was a great experience. I think that the way you have organized the projects really contributes to their success--there aren't a lot of gray areas. And I loved getting to work with such a worthy organization in my immediate community. It was an interesting challenge to market a non-profit rather than technology and I really enjoyed that as well. I have a couple of recommendations:  1) In the orientation, talk about the time expectations for different roles. The time expectation that was set was 3-5 hours per week and it was definitely more than that during the first phase of the project. Then it calmed down. That's understandable and it's fine--I just think you should set that expectation.  2) Add some more RBs to the examples on the site.

column41: Things took longer for everyone than expected

column47: Overall I think this project moved smoothly. The only recommendation I have is to reconsider the size of the team. As someone who manages non-profit communications, I feel that a smaller team would streamline the process and cut back on a lot of back and forth emailing.

Since it is a pro bono opportunity, I would imagine the team will be flexible and work with the team member on their challenges so that the entire team can complete the project together.  I just feel sending an email to resign from the job is very unprofessional.

column41: There was a lack of understanding on the part of the non-profit exactly what they had signed up for causing several starts & stops (project took close to 12 mos).  In addition to the length of time, during the "let's go" periods the project work and speed requested to complete tasks was beyond the 3-5 hours per week.  I understand that Taproot can only estimate time commitments, but I felt that there was a bigger gap than would be reasonable.
column47: I would like to see better up front ground rules set during the grant phase.  I think in this case the non-profit didn't know what it was signing up for when applying for and given the grant.  I've talked to others who I met during orientation when I was at a mixer over the summer and I believe my experience is not typical.  I would look forward to volunteering again.

column40: The client was excellent, especially the main point of contact (Viviana Knowles).  They were professional, positive, collaborative, and very easy to work with.  They brought great energy and enthusiasm to the project, and were great partners.
column41: I was disappointed with the level of effort, commitment, and professional expertise of the other Taproot volunteers on the team, with the exception of one (Susan Campbell -- see note below for details about her).    - One member of the team dropped out immediately (she wasn't replaced).    - Another member dropped out unexpectedly halfway through, at a very critical point in the project, in a very unprofessional manner.    - A third member did some work, but the quality was very low, and most of that work had to be redone.    - And the fourth member did no visible work on the project whatsoever.    If it hadn't been for Susan Campbell, I would have carried the project completely on my own, and I would have been very frustrated and discouraged by the experience.
column47: I highly commend Susan Campbell, who is a top-notch professional.  She is intelligent, knowledgeable about her field, highly committed, reliable, and goes above and beyond expectations to deliver high-quality results.  I very much appreciated her input on the team -- she created a strong portion of the final deliverables.  I would highly recommend her, and would welcome the opportunity to work with her again.

column40: Helping this worthy organization better market themselves to donors, customers and other stakeholders. This will enhance their fundraising opportunities, product sales, name recognition and community support.
column41: We were doing very well on time at first. But, the client had big initiatives that they were focused on that delayed the project. That made it difficult for our team to stay energized to complete the service grant. The materials from Taproot while helpful, are a bit confusing when you have never done a project before. Once we got the hang of it all, we did fine.

column47: I am a little disappointed in how this project ended for our team. I (as the AD) had specifically asked the Taproot program manager to have the final celebration be something I work on not the Project Manager. It was given to the PM who does not have time for Taproot initiatives. As a result, after one attempt to coordinate dates for a get together, nothing further was done. It is now a little too late to reach out to the team again as everyone seems to have moved on. While I appreciate the effort to have a formal party, just getting a thank you note from Growing Home would have been nice. I, as the AD, have heard nothing from anyone at Growing Home. My team and I worked very hard for them. Happily, I would do it again. They are terrific people. Just disappointed that we received no acknowledgement from them for our efforts.

column21: Court Appointed Special Advocate (CASA) - PG County
column40: For me, contributing a marketing plan for the nonprofit (in terms of recruiting Board members and volunteer staff. It was a creative contribution based upon my previous work experience as Executive Director of a nonprofit.  The client specifically mentioned this piece as very helpful.
column41: Team:  Account Director barely participated and did not come to 2 critical meetings with client.  I was asked to take on some of her assigned tasks because she "was too busy", which I did (no problem), because this was my first project and I wanted to do an excellent job and be a good team player.  Also, initial team was to be 4-person, but before we even got started 1 person dropped out.  Between that loss and the relative lack of work from the Account Director, it was basically a two-person team (Project Manager and me).  We still managed to do a good job, but I was disappointed in the overall performance of the Account Director, who seemed to do little other than to tell the Project Manager what to do.  The Project Manager was capable but was not well-suited (experience-wise) to this project and did not select templates to use very well (which I helped to correct). Her style of presentation to client was to read verbatim the words on the slidedeck, which everyone could already read themselves.  Also, Account Director called project to an end sooner than necessary because she wanted to "wind it up".  We finished 4 weeks early (according to project plan) and we could have used that time to better assess and engage current and new Board members.  Granted, the Board of this client was not very responsive to participation in this service grant, but the few that did were committed and interested.  I feel we could have done more for them and was surprised when told by A.D./P.M. that an upcoming meeting was to be our last.
column47: Even though my opinion is not the best of my former team members, I gained excellent experience with Taproot, worked very hard on it, and contributed a lot of expertise and time.  I now feel I have a much better grasp of how projects work.  I have already been asked to serve on another team as Project Manager (the Mobile Medical award) with A.D. Joan Sterling, and am really looking forward to this next opportunity!

column40: Helping the client look at their NP with fresh eyes and see some internal questions that needed answering.
column41: The client seemed indecisive and didn't have a clear direction in which they wanted to proceed. Each time we seemed to be making progress, they would backtrack and show us different examples of logos they liked, but couldn't explain why they liked them or how they could be relevant to their NP. Also, our team maybe didn't appear to present a united front and provide the much needed direction that the client evidently needed.
column47: I think there were many different issues that compounded together to make this grant incomplete. From the get go, we never had a Project Manager and it always felt like we were floundering and doing the best we could with what we had. I don't know if there's any way to put a project on hold until a complete team can be assembled. These teams are small, it's the first time working together and with a new client, I think it became very apparent that each team member and role is vital. That might have had a bearing on the overall outcome, maybe not.

column41: I spoke to someone at Taproot regarding the issues we experienced with an inexperienced Brand Manager and a highly combative copywriter who also doesn't have any agency (marketing/ad) background nor understands marketing basics. The Account Director and I had to do pick  up a lot of the work that was assigned to those individuals, which made this experience very difficult. There was great tension every time we had a team meeting due to the writer's combative nature and caused a lot of frustration between the Account Director, Project Manager and myself. I went through a rigorous process to become a Taproot volunteer. I recommend that the interview process is reviewed so that the talent is on par with the scope of work for a project.  This was my second one project. I hope my third one is nothing like this. Or else it will make me question whether I want to continue being a Taproot volunteer.

column40: Just the experience of working through my initial project.

The Pro Bono Team was distracted by their job responsibilities.  The client was supportive but not enthusiastic.  The client's BOD saw 6 of 10 members resign during the project.

column47: The volunteer matching process was frustrating. I think it would be more effective for volunteers to be able to "drop" their resumes into a pool for each project, specifying which role they would feel they are best suited for, and allow the AD to decide.
