column40: The most rewarding part of the project was delivering a new visual identity that will impact Metropolitan Family Services in numerous ways. I also enjoyed working with Liz Sacks and Rachel Neft from my Taproot Team and Ann Pinkney from MFS.
column41: There were a number of frustrations that I felt throughout the project:  1. Metropolitan Family Services has a full marketing staff -- Marketing Director, Creative Director and Graphic Designer. It made me wonder why they needed Taproot and that maybe our services would have been more beneficial to a smaller non-profit with no marketing staff.  2. Metropolitan Family Services had numerous changes to the logos choices that went above and beyond the scope of work. I was happy to make changes at first -- I want them to have the best logo they can have. But after a while, it was pretty ridiculous.  3. Our Account Director, Marcia Lehman gave little to no input on the entire project. Our Project Manager, Larry Munson didn't seem to have a very good understanding of our roles and the scope of the project. I found myself doing a lot of the project manager tasks -- ie attending meetings with the clients, taking notes, sending emails to the team, scheduling, etc.

column40: Creating meaningful messaging that the board and client team immediately reacted to with a positive reaction.
column41: Bad pro bono team candidates, lack of qualified talent for the team...plus misrepresented skills that became a real liability to the project.
column46: Taproot needs to rectify volunteer hiring practices before I can recommend the org
column47: It took months to staff the project, and then I was forced to select from less than qualified volunteers to get started. It proved to be a nightmare. Two of us ended up getting the job done. After 5 projects, I won't take on another one until the recruitment issues are resolved.

column40: Working with excellent volunteer team members and excellent client team members all of whom wanted to do excellent work for the client.
column41: Nothing stands out as being unusually frustrating or difficult. The positives far outweighed any low level frustrations. One low-level frustration was making adjustments to the Excel TimeLine form toward the end of the process which was difficult due to the way Taproot formated it.
column42: Debbie Steele, Liz Sacks, Marcia Lehman
column47: (1) Taproot could gain by providing Project Managers with an organizational system to help keep the many emails, computer documents, printed documents, and meeting minutes in an organized, condensed way. (2) I (as Project Manager) would have liked greater clarity on the specific steps I needed to take to close the project. (3) It would also help for Taproot to provide guidance to the Project Manager on moving forward when neither the Account Director nor the Project Manager had ever worked on a Taproot project previously. (4) In conclusion, simply said, I loved working on this project with this team and this client.

column40: A happy client.
column41: Two of the team members were not qualified for their assigned roles.
column47: The person assigned as our brand strategist was very junior and very green and not capable of taking a lead role.  This was very damaging to the project and put a great deal of additional responsibility on the AD.  In addition, the copywriter had no experience with writing marketing copy and seemed incapable of adapting his style.  This again put undue pressure on the AD who was the only one on the team who could plug the gap.  This resulted in delays and many frustrations, which fortunately, we were able to keep out of the client's eye.

However, the nonprofit worked with a printer who gave them such a good price that the printing cost was comparable to a project that complied with the blueprint.

My group did a good job of giving me feedback during the comp stage. Positive feedback and good constructive criticism is always a good thing and helps to develop a final product that meets the needs of the client.  It was a pleasure working with this talented group and would work with them again. All but one member of the group were very professional, put egos aside and made St Dominic School the focus.  Teresa Scaletta was great at keeping us focused, on track and on time.
column41: Sometimes the group got mixed up on the weekly phone conference date and time. The Account Director and Project manager always were able to catch us up on what was missed. Sometimes with static or background noise I wasn't able to hear all that was said. But all I had to do was ask to explain or clarify and they did with no problem. Account Director and Project Manager always made sure we understood what our next steps were.

column47: I found that the essential structure of working with 4 other people who are not in any way connected to be frustrating. We had weekly conference calls which, I felt, did not work very well. Almost every one of them was inefficient and, occasionally, maddening. I joined the group late as the original designer had to drop out a couple of months into the project, so it is possible that this shook up the process a lot.  There was one member of the team who was absent from the calls most of the time and then, when he did choose to call in, made demands that were inappropriate at that particular stage of the project. He seemed to feel that the client just didn' t know what they wanted and that we should do whatever we (read he) wanted and basically tell them that we were right and they were wrong. He would go over things thhat we had been working on for weeks without his input and expect vast changes even after the client had approved everything. In the end he just disappeared.   Having said all of that I did very much enjoy working with Marie Bareille, the writer. We got together and worked independantly quite a bit and I thought that aspect worked very well.  The bottom line is that I think not being in the same space with the people you are creating with does not work efficiently.

column41: where to begin. the project was never managed. the designer presented the wires and designs to the client before the team had a chance to review them. we skipped many important steps - that eventually led to the massive delay of the project. For example, we didn't review or define tech specs or functional specs at the beginning, so we ended up answering the many questions around those subjects during the build.  we didn't really review the wires since the client already signed off on them when they were presented to us, which led to massive misunderstandings, designs that didn't match the wires, and delayed the project because we had to build and rebuild. the project manager dropped out as the project dragged on and the account director stepped in and started looking at deliverables at the 11-th hour. at which point she fought hard for the client's pov, and made us go above and beyond to answer the client's wishes and demands, when those wishes and demands were out of scope or not according to the signed off wires / designs, which did not match each other. a cyclical mess.

column40: Delivering a quality website that met the objectives of The Community House as well as ensuring that they could sustain on their website on their own moving forward.

column42: Everyone on the team was a great collaborator. One person had family issues and I covered some of her responsibilities.
column47: I truly enjoyed my experience as a Taproot volunteer and completing a new website for The Community House  a third grant with the Taproot Foundation.  I learned a lot about marketing for a non-profit organization with new website tools and resources and enjoyed collaborating with a great group of professionals interested in community service.  The Community House was a challenging website project that required developing a new user friendly website with quite a bit of streamlining of existing content while elevating awareness of all program offerings. The Taproot volunteers on the project Monika Chodkiewicz  Graphic Designer, Patrick DiMichele - Project Manager and Information Architect, Becky Heneghan-Gonzalez  Marketing Manager, Bennett Neuhauser  content writer, and Kurt Olsen  Website Developer were outstanding.  They brought an exceptional skillset and provided loads of experience, ideas, feedback and alternatives throughout the entire process and did so with enthusiasm and a strong commitment the quality, completion and sustainability of the website.   The Community House staff was truly collaborative with everyone on the project committed to the success of the website.  We had non-technical personnel especially, Dan Janowick, step up to lead and meet project needs, but also had board members, Christine Schwartz and Amy Gaber, and department leads , Kari Moore and Sara Sieracki, provide great direction on the goals and scope, architecture, design  and content needs for the website.  Jeni Fabian's timing as the new Executive Director helped us move forward confidently with each milestone and feeling gratified that they could sustain the website on their own.   The Community House helped to maintain a strong momentum with their continuous expression of appreciation to the Taproot volunteers for their time and effort.  The Taproot Foundation is great organization I recommend other marketers to join.  They provide invaluable time and talent for non-profit organizations with limited marketing resources to further their causes.   I was impressed from the beginning with the amount of resources available and step-by-step, documented processes to make each milestone in the project as well as the final outcome a success.  This was especially helpful for me as a first time volunteer directing a team of volunteers.   As an Account Director, you need to be prepared to jump in and fill any gaps in the process of completing a Taproot project.  I was appreciative of the guidance from the program directors, Joshua Brown, who was an amazing sounding board, and Miriam Young, who helped me close out the project.   I was also able to reach out to other Account Directors and post questions to other volunteers and recommend that everyone take more advantage of all opportunities to network with other Taproot members.

column41: The most frustrating aspect was finding out that in fact the client wasn't having a problem in adding bodies to its board.  It did have a problem with strategic focus generally and this meant it was not possible to provide specific recruitment strategies, only generic ones.  It also turned out that the client was making very poor utilization of existing board members and needed a lot of direction about board self management (an essential component of building a good reputation as a desirable board to serve on which is in turn essential component for effective board recruiting).  It was initially frustrating that Taproot and the account manager hadn't identified these problems at the grant approval stage...  I think this is due to the fact that this grant is perhaps too narrowly constructed in the first place.  It should be situated in a somewhat wider 'readiness for good governance' assessment process.
column47: We could have used a better process for managing the board self-assessment questionnaires. column40: I would probably have never discovered this nonprofit company myself. It was very interesting to get an insider's view of the company, especially to learn how nonprofit people think and how the nonprofit culture is different from what I typically experience in the corporate world. I felt strongly emphatic with the company's objectives. They were very friendly and gave us a lot of goodwill and trust.
column41: In my opinion, the more senior (age-wise) members of the team struggled with the technologies and time management through the whole project. Our meetings, both internal and facing the client, were very long and lacked the efficiency that modern communication tools provide (such as presentations, use of computers in general). Team meetings were excruciatingly long, with most time spent going back on forth on the single question of what the goal of the project was. And in this regard comes the main reason for my frustration: I strongly believed that our final deliverable was not corresponding to the purpose of the project.  Specifically, instead of educating the client about the process of strategic planning, senior members of the team got too involved into providing the client with very specific recommendations that were not based on any expertise or knowledge in the field. Some of the recommendations and suggestions were offensive to the feelings of the client, in my strong opinion. Also, I was really shocked about the misuse of confidential information from third parties: as a phase of the project, we interviewed various third parties such as members of other dance companies, theater staff and even governmental officials. During the interviews, we never mentioned that the response can be shared verbatim with our client, and in some instances we actually promised confidentiality to the interviewees; however, to make the final report more "credible" and create a "wow" factor, the managers in the team insisted on giving the client the transcripts of all interviews, disclosing the names of interviewees and their responses close to verbatim. Within the team, we argued about it to no avail. I am bewildered by this experience, because in the corporate world it would have likely created legal problems, and as far as the client goes, I imagine that they are likely to feel hurt reading what people said about them thinking that BDC would not know. It serves no purpose and would likely make BDC regret their decision to pursue the Taproot grant. This is very unprofessional.
column47: It was my first project, while Olga's second or third. column40: I know that we provided a website that will help low-income women find affordable healthcare. And we added an entire Spanish-language section to the MayView site--something they had never had despite many of their clients only speaking Spanish.
column41: The client said they wanted a new site, and for the most part they were responsive to what needed to happen to get a new one up and running, but their overall attitude seemed passive and not all that excited.   That concern has been borne out by the fact that there were a few things they needed to do to really finish the site that they have not yet done two months later. For example, our web guru, Chris, told them how to fix an alignment issue that's causing the headline to butt up against the top banner on some pages (e.g. Locations-->Palo Alto and News and Events-->Calendar, just to name two). I know enough HTML to realize that it would take about 5-10 minutes to fix all the pages, yet they still haven't done it. Nor have they finished filling in the Spanish-language pages.  The real kicker was when they admitted to our account director, Linda, right at the end of the project that, "we never intended to rewrite any of our material." In other words, they just wanted a prettier website; they didn't care whether the copy was effective or not.  They also said, "Patty's content guidelines were for new content; we aren't writing anything from the beginning for this project." Of course my guidelines weren't just for new copy; they were also for making existing copy clearer and more succinct.  I should note that they did end up using my intro copy for the new section home pages. Also, JoAnn Cabrera's existing copy was good, although I think she was under pressure from Shamima to put in a lot of extra text. At one point, they wanted to put most of their annual report on one page; we convinced them to summarize it and provide a link to a PDF. So the text didn't end up badly at all. But for them to pretend all along that they would accept the help of a writer/editor when in fact they had no intention of doing so was extremely deceptive.  I'm proud of the work I did on site organization/navigation and writing new copy for the home page and section home pages. But I was working on the assumption that they really wanted my help, and obviously they didn't.   BTW, they never gave us an end-of-project party, either. It was just a normal meeting. They did have sandwiches; they had also provided food at our other 6:00 p.m. meetings. So that was nice. But there was nothing special about our last get-together. I could never tell whether Shamima wasn't really enthusiastic about the project or is just a very undemonstrative person. Anyway, what with the revelation of their not having wanted writing help plus not having anything that felt like a party, the end of the project was dissatisfying.
column46: The last time I suggested that someone work with Taproot, she was turned down even though she is a highly experienced project manager. Apparently Taproot now has more volunteers than projects (not the case when I started), and you don't need any more PMs or ADs. I don't recall the details, but I did get the impression that she was brushed off somewhat curtly. So I'm now less apt to suggest volunteering with Taproot to my friends.
column47: My first Taproot project was for a website (Breast Cancer Connections), and it went extremely well. Our ideas were welcomed warmly and implemented in full. We were even invited to some special BCC events as though we were major donors.   My second website, Support Network for Women, was a disaster, with SNBW's ED not standing up to a longtime volunteer who thought she ran the place and wanted to do all the design and writing herself (which is why their existing site was so bad), and with our AD not supporting his team when SNBW trashed our input.   Although the MayView project wasn't nearly that bad, it was obviously crushing to me to find out that all they really wanted was a new design; they never understood that the text of a website is just as important as the design for drawing people in, evoking the desired emotional response (such as relief that they've found a place that can help them), and giving them the information they need clearly and succinctly.   I think, therefore, that something needs to be changed in the screening process to make sure that the nonprofit understands how important it is for text and graphics to work together, and is truly committed to making the writing work well for their website visitors. As it stands now, it appears that nonprofits are saying, "Oh yes, we want a new website!" when all they really want is a pretty design and maybe more logical navigation. Somehow, Taproot needs to educate nonprofits on the importance of website text, and, as I said, make sure that they're on board with an ENTIRE website redesign before they're given a service grant.

The pattern I notice is that everyone is on board at the beginning, and I'm alone on an island as the designer at the end.

Some accomodation/customization for client situations should be encouraged.

column40: Nonprofit was committed to project and gave us access to high-level stakeholders and executive staff. The Taproot service grant team was of a very high caliber and worked together in a friendly, professional, productive manner. (Note the final team was different from the initial team.)
column41: The project had a very rocky start. The original account director was quite difficult to work with (did not take feedback well, not collaborative) and ended up leaving the project along with the project manager, who was a previous colleague. The experience did make me wonder about how prospective account directors are vetted and oriented into Taproot.
column42: Katy Mogal, Isabel Gilbert, Christine Buck
column47: Overall the new blueprints are much easier to work with. I do wonder if the project plan can be further simplified. Also, it's still a challenge to find an efficient collaboration site (Yahoo, Google, Basecamp) and wonder if Taproot could make recommendations for a simpler file share program (e.g., Dropbox).  This particular project was marked by a fair amount of people drama at the beginning, but once it became clear that the situation couldn't be resolved, I did feel that Taproot and the team moved quickly and decisively -- and most important, client confidence didn't suffer and the final deliverable was of very high quality.

column40: Learning another web tool (Joomla and multilingual support)
column41: Too much pessimism from the start as to client capability and dedication - quickly led to low expectations and a self-fulfilling prophecy. Account Director was the most negative.
column46: Would describe pros (challenges, non-profit) and cons (large teams, lots of structure)
column47: Powerpoint deck templates for meetings should emphasize the logistics and housekeeping checklists are only for team prep. Most of the actual meeting time with the client should be interactive and focussed on developing the meaningful content - web site goals, wireframes, site maps, etc. My first Taproot project meetings were perhaps too informal, but nonetheless were 99% working collaborations. This second project had meetings that were 90% walking through boring slides with very little interaction between the team and client.

column40: Seeing their faces when they saw the quality of the deliverables and how it could help them achieve their mission.

column47: My wife Sandra Hoover and I have been involved in 3 Taproots projects, and one common theme is that usually anywhere from 1 - 3 people are too busy with their regular jobs to complete the tasks they committed to. This results in meetings with the client where not all of us showed up, and the deadline extended numerous times because one of the Taproots members was so busy with her work and personal life, that her task was delayed, postponed, and extended.   It would be beneficial to know when people sign up to be part of a team, that they can give the time they are committing to, to help it be a successful project.

column40: Being retired, I enjoy the intellectual stimulation of working on projects that I know so well and trying to mentor younger team members on the differences between consulting to a client and being an inside HR professional. column41: 1. While most of the volunteers on the team were competent and dedicated, a couple individuals in particular were very weak - both in terms of skill set and engagement.  This brought down morale for the whole team, as well as resulted in a late and low quality deliverable.  While I understand that Taproot relies on volunteers for their projects, it was disappointing to me that Taproot as an organization would be comfortable pawning such poor quality work off on a nonprofit client who depends on our efforts, when it would never be acceptable in the corporate world to do that. 2. The PM was unable to keep the team motivated and ensure quality of deliverables.  The AM, while involved heavily in the beginning, did not step in and appropriate checkpoints to ensure timely delivery or quality of work.
column46: Not based on the experience that I had, though I know others have had very positive experiences
column47: If Taproot wants to treat their nonprofit clients as clients, then they should treat their volunteer staff as they would project hires. That means reasonable screening for proof of skill set before staffing them on a project. It's great that volunteers can use Taproot experience to reinforce their own skill set, but they shouldn't be using nonprofits in that way just to build their portfolios, while giving them second rate, half-a$$ed work that would never be acceptable to give to a client otherwise.  I joined Taproot because it came highly recommended to me by friends (specifically, the NY branch), and so I'll consider this past experience a one-off.  I'd be willing to do one more project with Taproot and hope for the best, before I make a decision about where to put my volunteer time in.

One member was suddenly scheduled to make a presentation for her (paying) employer on the day of the final deliverable presentation and one very key member of the Client Team left the non-profit's employ. We worked around all the obstacles, the deadlines (except for the presentation of the final product) were all met comfortably.

column47: My career has focused mostly on research environments and working with such a human-focused organization was a real change for me. I found the entire experience very valuable and genuinely look forward to my next project (after winter).  The Client organization, as mentioned, was wonderful to work with: helpful, receptive, transparent, communicative and grateful beyond my expectations. They awarded my entire team HONORARY MEMBERSHIPS for 2012 and have welcomed us to participate in all future events! (None of us are of Japanese heritage, incidentally.)  This team has been great to work with. My understanding is that this project was more complex than most Taproot assignments and it had, as described, a number of hiccups along the way. However, the entire Team remained upbeat, flexible and pulled together to make certain that high-quality deliverables were produced and presented to the Client at every step.

We got a sense that client was not ready to use the results of our study because they had very fundamental issues and they couldnt possibly use the findings from the SWOT analysis. Also, I don't think the client had a clear idea , at the start of the project, of how to use the SWOT.

column47: About project:  The client was not ready for CCA. They did not even have a clear strategic plan in place - so there was no clearly useful way to evaluate competitors/collaborators. While I believe that our team and the client understood that and we contributed effectively as much as we could -  I believe that the grant should have been for strategic planning and not CCA - I feel that the CCA work that we did, was not particularly relevant to the current state of the client needs.   For taproot (general, not this project related): I would like to be able to express an interest in developing specific (2-3) professional skills or contribute in multiple specific interest areas in my Taproot profile.

Our engagement was Performance Management so confidentiality should not have been a real issue and where it may have been that info could be blocked out. column47: This was a great project and the client was very interesting to work with. The only challenge with the client was the speed at which their work is evolving, which is great for them but was somewhat frustrating on a Taproot team that is trying to get copy approved. Not a big deal, though. The time we lost replacing one and losing a second MM  resulted in a rush at the end of the process, which gave the client less time to review designs and comps. Far from optimal.  I was very lucky to work with a qualified, lovely and fun group of teammates from Taproot. Very dedicated to the cause and committed to the project. The support from Taproot was essential and I depended on Skip's guidance and email instructions on each stage of the process. Loved working with him.   In the beginning, I found the Blueprint and all the Taproot material completely overwhelming. Plus a lot of the terminology and acronyms were new to me and took a little while to get the hang of it. That being said, the structure and in-depth descriptions were a godsend and contributed significantly in a successful outcome.  I would have preferred meeting with my Taproot team in person during the final stages of the project. However, that was not possible for a number of reasons. I think it would have expedited the discussions on creative and copy.  The main thing I would do differently next time is interviewing potential candidates much more thoroughly. I did pursue the issue of conflict-of-interest with our first MM before the project started and she said she was fine with proceeding. Perhaps our experience was unavoidable, but I would still spend more time with candidates.    Overall, a wonderful experience and I look forward to delving into another project.

column47: I think there's a disconnect between team members with very busy professional lives, who are taking on a project for fun or for other personal reasons, and the client's intensity and needs. Although not known when the Taproot grant was made, the client spiraled downward toward survival mode.  That level of angst and urgency was out of sync with the complacency of some team members and lack of perspective by others.

In the meantime, the project completed in June and the new CCI website still isn't live and I can't say I'm surprised. On the positive side, it gave me a new and deeper appreciation of working in a professional environment and made me realize how important it is to be compensated for your efforts.

This really increased the burden of being the project manager. While I feel we had a good outcome on this project for the client, it has really left me gun shy to volunteer for another project.

(2) I think the Account Director missed an opportunity when he was not on every one of our weekly calls. He was busy with his own consulting work and had several conflicts.   (3) I sometimes felt the client was so busy (this is their busiest time of the year), that they seemed a bit less engaged. column40: The most rewarding part was the content of the work itself. When I finally received the go-ahead and necessary feedback from the client, the pages that needed writing--and the elements of International House that needed describing--made for very engaging content. Based on what I learned about I-House during the process, I would definitely recommend the institution to a student who might be a fit for the place. It's a very interesting organization, and it was very easy to make writing its content fun.   Second place prize goes to our account director (Vaughan Acton), coder (Panagiotis Panayotopoulos), and designer (ML Haynes). They were very professional and I would recommend them highly to anyone looking at their respective services.
column41: The International House clients are incredibly intelligent and very professional--when they engage. The challenge was getting them to meet any sort of deadline. They wouldn't just miss; they'd miss by weeks and sometimes months. I realize they are busy, but at times the Taproot team wondered privately if this was truly an urgent project to them. Which is a shame because, like I said, when they did engage, they were some of the brightest and most thoughtful clients I have ever worked with in any capacity.    Bottom line: I wouldn't exclude any of these clients, or I-House in general, based on the slipping deadlines, but Taproot should clarify some ground rules when the organization re-engages with I-House on the latter's next project.

column47: It is important to make sure all understand the role they play and what is expected to fulfill that role. For example, meeting management and participant expectations, creative presenting, gaining agreement/closure. These areas have action items that fall between roles and could delay the project process particularly if the knowledgeable person(s) do not realize he/she can just pick up the ball and person(s) without the knowledge fill-in without enough information...just taking up time. Fortunately, this is not a big deal, but could cause an issue if everyone is not on the same page or have the same expectations.

column41: As Account Director (and later Account Director/Project Manager), the logistics of getting everyone to commit to deadlines and regular updates was problematic.  This had nothing to do with the quality of the work or the personalities involved---we did develop a real chemistry as a team.  But the fact that most of the discussions took place outside of regular working hours, on weekends and evenings, was at times difficult to coordinate (if unavoidable).  In addition, given the protracted nature of the assignment, there was something of a fatigue factor that took place about two-thirds of the way through.  Again, I think this is a function of the fact that we were all doing this on a part-time, limited basis, which was counter to our work instincts.  But overall, we developed a genuine rapport and mutual respect.

column47: Linkedin.com recommendations might be a great way for Taproot Foundation management to show further appreciation to those individuals that worked far beyond the call of duty in their effort to deliver professional-grade products. The second-most frustrating part for me was when the photographer suggested a cover photo that had nothing to do with the organization and was not suggested by anything in the Discovery interviews or Requirements brief, and the client and rest of the team jumped on board with that, agreeing to add references to this concept in the copy and images throughout the annual report. Of course, when it came to the copy, the client-side writer did not include any references to this idea and edited out most of my references in the copy I touched.

Money makes the world go round.

column41: I think it is hard for a new group of people to come together and immediately start working well. People are concerned about seeming to be too demanding, and therefore don't call others out or ask enough questions of team members in the early stages. I think Taproot should require teams to meet in person at least two or three times before they meet with the client. I felt that I barely knew my team when we met with the client for the first time, so it was tough to present ourselves as a cohesive team.
column46: I would, but with the caveat that it does take a lot of time.
column47: If possible, I think Taproot should try to staff people as soon as possible after they sign up. I signed up and attended orientation in August, only to wait until February to start a project. I had lost a little bit of the excitement I felt upon first signing up, and my schedule was much busier in Jan/Feb so I probably would not have signed up at that point. I know I had the option not to take the project, but also I'd figured that if it took this long to get staffed, it might be much longer before my name came up again.   All that said, I think it's awesome that Taproot exists and I was actually pretty amazed at how well our project went, considering it was all pro-bono from six very business professionals!

column47: This project showed me just how much better my last one (for Los Angeles Child Guidance Clinic) could have gone. This time, there was a culture of gratitude among our team that was clearly missing on Team LACGC. I didn't realize Taproot consultants and clients were supposed to be as kind and appreciative until I worked with this group. The words "thank you" go such a long way, so does letting everyone take ownership of their job, which we really had with Westside Family. On LACGC, it may have been overly collaborative.

column46: Glad the project is over; would not recommend volunteering with Taproot.
column47: My experience was a thoroughly negative one.   I found the completion of the Taproot forms to be onerous. The forms are redundant, requiring the same information to be presented a myriad of different ways. Much of the information requested is not something a project manager would know. Simply, there's too much to fill out, too much to read through, and too much to send to Taproot and client. The schedule in Excel was particularly perplexing and user-unfriendly.   The client regularly ignored emails, a problem which delayed the project for months.  Several team members were unresponsive. They didn't take the commitment seriously; in turn I found myself caring less and less. As project manager I was only able to do so much reminding. After a time, I simply stopped expecting to hear from them.   Some kept us waiting for weeks with continual excuses, rather than just bowing out of the project gracefully.  When the project languished, I was caught between the team members who didn't fulfill their obligations, and a project director who would press me to keep things moving.  The graphic designer showed an appalling lack of know-how as far as design principles and design software. As a designer myself, I was embarrassed by some of the shoddy drafts she submitted and mistakes she made.

column41: We had one member of the team that was clearly on the project for self gain (cache, etc).  This person arrived to 99% of all meetings late (if at all) and was at times, generally unprofessional; particularly when the Account Director was not present.  This person delegated nearly every task and, once they began working a day job, pretty much check out leaving the team to make up the slack.  The client was slow to respond at times.  Also I got the feeling that they wanted us to magically "DO" everything for them versus make recommendations for action that required work on their part.  I hope in spite of this they found our work valuable.
column47: I think that recruiters for the HR Capacity grants should work with a seasoned HR professional (as a partner) to get a sense for what is really required in the field of HR in way of experience and technical expertise in order to be successful on a grant.  The recruiters relied heavily on self reported experience on.  This has the potential to leave non profits with holes in their evaluations by inexperienced, "self reported" HR professionals.  Such gaps could have serious legal consequences.  HR is very broad but wrought with legal implications.  Unlike graphic design or photography that is largely subjective and without legal implications (aside from trademark), poor HR advice can close the doors on a company.  Perhaps a prequalification document that prompts recruiters to ask questions in each of several key areas, law, benefits, wage and hour, etc.  None of these questions were asked of me, luckily my resume (and profile) are truthful and largely understated.  I'd be happy to help with something like this if there is interest.

However, they frequently missed regularly scheduled weekly team phone calls and often did not reply to emails about issues until things became significant problems which wasted project time and caused real distress. Any project of this complexity needs a committed leader/manager, volunteer or not. Our project suffered from this lack of leadership.

column47: I believe Taproot needs to be more realistic about the significant time investment involved for copywriters on a website service grant. A copywriter must be involved with the discovery interviews in order to capture the nuance and voice of the organization -- it's not possible to glean that from the interview notes that the marketing manager takes (they're not verbatim, they miss some of the tone, and that's frankly not what they're looking for). And as copywriting goes hand-in-glove with the design, the copywriter really can't "miss" that part either. I spent waaaay more time than 100 hours total on this project -- it became a full/part time job for about 4 months. I feel Taproot needs to be up-front about the time it takes to do this particular aspect of the project.

column47: Thanks for the opportunity to share a few suggestions.  My main observation is that the team structure could be changed to speed the project - which I see as a problem for clients and a unneccesary requirement on the volunteers.  I think that larger teams may make it easier to progress projects faster. I believe this would be well received by the clients. I think the length of the project cuts into momentum and ultimately adds considerably to the overall requirements for volunteers. If there were 2 more 'functional' roles on the team the project would progress 2 months quicker and probably better. I suggest the account director role has functional requirements in addition to client mangement and the project management role be taken on by the junior recruitment advisor. Add to this an extra role that could be functional in marketing or recruitment to share the work and it would make it more robust and ultiamtely progress quicker. All of this is seen through my perspective where we lost a team-member part way through the project but even with that consideration I felt that more practical and functional roles on the team would exponentially increase the speed and robustness of the product.   Formal project management guidelines seemed overly detailed for the pace and complexity of the project - especially when there was a full PM role. I feel that the project management guides are playing to the lowest denominator which if we are staffing with professionals shouldn't be required.  The templates for presentations are EXTREMELY buggy and not easy and good to work with. this really affected my enjoyment of the project. It made what should have been exciting (putting together findings) an uneccesary pain. They look great and the content is good, but the templates themselves are not put together well on the Board recruitment project.  Overall I had a great time and will definitely do it again. I enjoyed my colleagues and the clients were fantastic. PCC is a great group of professionals that will continue on their path to growth through their talent and passion alone. I  strongly encourage Taproot to continue their support of PCC.  Thanks again for the opportunity, I thoroughly enjoyed it and feel great at the kind and warm reception from Taproot and the client upon completion.

column40: It always feels good to use my skill set to help a worthy cause. Also, there is no more appreciative client than a non-profit.
column41: TOO MANY MEETINGS! TOO MUCH PAPERWORK. This was a tri-fold brochure! Why did we have to have a weekly status call? Why did it take 3 months before we started the creative process? Why, did we spend so much time doing research and interviews and meetings, only to have it so that we were in a time crunch requiring copy and graphic design to happen almost simultaneously? What were all these briefs that had to be written? We produced enough paperwork for an annual report. What did all these people on our team do? There were like 3 account productionish people. I have no idea what they did besides schedule meetings and ask me when I'd be done?  I felt like everything took forever, we had seemingly unlimited amounts of time to create project briefs, outlines, conduct interviews, but when it came time for design, it was two weeks over Christmas. But worse, whenever I had a design deadline, the team would be on my ass about it, only to have me turn it in and find out that the next time the team could get together to discuss the design was in two weeks! Two weeks would pass, we'd have the meeting, everyone would say "this is good," then we'd shcedule a meeting with our clients for two weeks after that. All of this wouldn't tick me off so much, if after the meeting with the client, everyone didn't turn around and start pressuring me to try and finish all their changes as quickly as possible because we were now "running behind schedule."  I found the whole thing rathering frustrating and a huge drag on my time for a one page, tri-fold brochure.
column46: I would recommend it, but I would also warn them regarding my experience.
column47: I think this is a great organization with a really unique service, but streamline it. I can produce a global advertising campaign with TV, print and a website in the time it took to create this one brochure. And I can do it with half the number of meetings.

column41: The amount of work required was much more than communicated or anticipated. As a project manager, I felt my role was to facilitate logistics and project milestones, but found myself leading discussions, steering decisions, and managing the team.  When questions or next steps were discussed among the team, everyone would remain silent and wait or defer to me for responses and decisions. While team members completed their tasks and deliverables well, I did not feel that they stepped up to their roles as much as they could. I put a lot of work into making sure things were organized and documents were clear, to help people prepare for discussions prior to our weekly calls. But it was repeatedly apparent that no one reviewed items beforehand, requiring me to walk people through discussion points.   I expressed my concerns about people not stepping up and feeling like the burden of the project was mainly on my shoulders. While he said he could see and understand my concerns, he was not proactive about making other team members increase their participation. His style was to sit back, listen, and observe, to see if everyone stepped up. Needlesstosay, this did not work nor help to fix or alleviate my concerns. The AD was too hands off and I would have liked to see someone more assertive. It was clear the team was often deferring to his insight and guidance since he is a seasoned Taproot volunteer, but he would defer to me instead of making decisions or taking charge.

column41: Overall, it was very frustrating. Having to get on a weekly conference call after working a really long day was a large time requirement and often  a waste of that time. We also had one difficult team member who was undiplomatic in expressing her opinions (sometimes valid, sometimes bizarre/unqualified) of others' work - this made the calls really unpleasant and longer than necessary. My work was definitely not of the caliber or quality I'm capable because my time became extremely limited over the course of the project and the calls occupied too much of the time that I had available. And in the end, the client was unhappy with the project. It was a thankless experience.

column41: Working with an Account Manager who didn't "get" it, that is, did not acknowledge that her (poor) staffing decisions undermined both her own and the team's credibility with the client; was more than willing to do less than her best and require the best from the team, because "we aren't getting paid for this"; portrayed herself as a victim ... I could go on, but I think you get the idea. Essentially, the Account Manager was not a leader, she seemed to be biding her time on the project.
column47: I would suggest that Account Managers, in particular, have strong EQ's---emotional intelligence, common sense and savvy---since it is a given that they are professionally skilled. The value of "fit" and empathy cannot be overstated when developing relationships with clients.  Also, Account Managers should ensure that prospective team members have experience in their roles; "hire" team members and when appropriate, get examples of their past work, rather than staffing projects with people who are well-meaning but unqualified.

column40: We came up with a lot of good data for Histroy San Jose and really heard them out and tried to incorporate our learnings into the deliverable. HSJ appreciated our honest feedback and attempts at creating structure within the organization.
column41: I guess, one of the most challenging bits was that the scope of the project widened considerably with the organization wanting to question and re-questiona and re-examine the mission and vision. The assumption was that all that had been agreed upon by all board members and staff before our project began, and that we as the Project team wouldn't be extending our time into helping them structure that. The project went on for way longer than mandated and started demanding a lot of time and attention beyond the timeline decided on. This led to some personal frustration because my work commitments increased as well. The project team deserves respect and all team members attention, and this became tough with work and personal commitments mounting up. I hadn't budgeted for the additional months and it was difficult working around some of those commitments.  Another area of deep concern was the associate director's involvement in the project. While he was involved for the first 2-3 months gradually, the team stopped hearing from him completely after a certain point. The AD would not attend meetings, answer emails, or work on the project AT ALL, leave alone interact with the client. I would have had no problems if the individual were to speak to the team and say 'hey I cant do this right now, and I have to back off' but to completey disappear without a word? It was very unprofessional and created strain on the team since now there were only 4 team members really working and racking their brains. Everyone's time is precious and work commitments are of paramount importance. I was deeply disappointed that the AD did not care to respect the project team enough.
column47: I love the concept of Taproot and the work it does. As well as the level of support provided in terms of access to materials.

column41: The team: The discovery phase was extremely painful. Unfortunately, the Marketing Manager is probably better suited for a Project Manager role. I had to spend far too much effort directing, editing and rewriting the discovery and requirements briefs. In the end, we settled for what I consider usable, but less than great documents. I do however respect the fact that the Marketing Manager did hang-in to the end. She is also a very nice person.  I was relieved when we finally moved to the copy phase, but quickly felt disheartened. I don't think the copywriter was a brochure writer. Fortunately, the Account Director is an experienced copywriter who rewrote and produced a fabulous first draft.
column47: The Taproot documentation is better than spot-on. I enjoyed the process but would respectfully recommend adding reference checks to the screening process.

That was very frustrating. I hope someone from Taproot spoke with her about that. Really unethical. The Account Director is very smart, but was going back/forth from micro-managing to being out of touch for weeks. It was frustrating how long the process took.

column40: The insightful discoveries are always rewarding - because it takes the partnering of the team and the client to get there.
column41: On my last two grants, the inconsistency of the team experiences/levels makes the project more challenging. I think that Taproot shouldn't take every volunteer - and should scare anyone away who thinks grants are easy, quick or a place to learn. Instead - it's a challenge far greater than a normal job because you are doing it on your own time, with team members you don't know and that you need to tap into your abilities beyond what the Taproot resource materials give. And - just because it's volunteer, doesn't mean that you can bail out when it's tougher than you anticipated. Taproot grants are meaningful work - so it demands way more effort than writing a check for a non-profit. It takes nimble, brilliant mindset from team members who are willing to run the ball across the goal line - even if they were on the bench.
column47: I think that the resource forms and examples are pretty good but I think that there is a big leap between the strategic findings and the creative. I find this problem with most projects - but not sure how to resolve it. Creative collaboration and inspiration is just as challenging as any real world project - maybe even harder because the grants have consolidated processes.

column40: As with all my taproot projects, the most rewarding part is how much the client learns during the process (beyond the deliverable itself). This grant was no exception to that. The Taproot process by definition allows this to happen.
column41: The most frustrating part for me was the disconnect between what the client needed and how the grant was originally awarded. Thankfully, the team was very strong, and was able to come up with a custom/tailored scope which ended up working very well for SLH. I personally was frustrated as this was a contradiction to the way I "sold" the project to my team when i was interviewing them - having done 2 grants before this, I strongly emphasized the Blueprint, the templates, etc. and none of this really supported our team.

column47: It was a thoroughly growth-enhancing experience, but the time requirements were completely off-based. When each internal/external interview required two individuals at each location--fighting LA traffic--that, in itself is a turn-off. Why more of this could not have been done virtually was ridiculous. I incurred a lot of expense in travel and time commitment. Plus being on a strategic planning team, it required a lot of desk research to make meaningful contributions. I felt the account manager was not at all flexible in recognizing time/travel constraints. In my professional life, I worked with colleagues in India. Why would I be required to spend 4 hours on the road to conduct a 30-min. interview (with another Taproot volunteer), when this is my volunteer activity? The priorities did not make sense.

column47: Keeping within scope was a major problem. Sometimes we were encouraged by the account director to go out of scope. At first I went a long with it but soon got overwhelmed with everything that was expected of me. In the future I will be VERY FIRM our need to stay within scope of the project.   Traveling to meetings was stressful at times. I wonder if a few in person meetings could be replaced with virtual meetings over the phone with screen sharing software.   We had two developers on this team and in my opinion neither of them were fit for the job. I think it boiled down to lack of experience with the CMS platforms. I'm disappointed with the final product. Even though I provided HTML and CSS to the developer, the end product is not up to par with my standards. There are alignment issues and the styles I created were not followed. There were also graphic changes that the client requested and I did for them, but the developer did not implement them into the site.

column47: Donor Database projects need BA experienced in not-for-profit fundraising, to advise clients on possibilities and best practices.  Salesforce is a very powerful (=complex) tool.  Significant effort is needed for team to understand Salesforce terminology, data model, capabilities and limitations.  It's a great platform for organizations willing and capable of extending into other operations; overkill for anyone else.  I, as AD, did a poor job in selecting team members.  BA was pleasant but incapable, and overcommitted to day job; DA was capable but unresponsive and overwhelmed by day job; SD#1 was unresponsive (dropped from team after missing four meetings and hour late for fifth); SD#2 was personable, committed, and capable, but after two months took on a new, demanding day job.  PM and I hoped too much that each of these would honor commitment; too many conf calls with just PM and AD present.

column41: A dysfunctional team: 1) An Account Manager who quit the project due to conflicts with the graphic designer which resulted in nobody to manage the conflicts on the team; 2) A graphic designer who did not want to take the advice of other subject experts on the team and who instead approached and influenced the client with his own preferences which contributed to extending the project 7-9 months beyond the originally planned completion date. 3) A copywriter who stopped participating in team conference calls and who instead partnered with the graphic designer, only to produce work that was not on strategy and ultimately not acceptable to the client.
column46: Not without sharing my frustrations
column47: As project manager, I think the blueprint is wonderfully extensive, yet woefully complex in its layout for a first time participant.  I believe it could be made much easier to follow and to use appropriately if reorganized.

column41: There were two hurdles in our project. First: several Taproot members dropped out so we struggled to maintain our group. At least one had a personal conflict so that's of course understandable. But others, such as Charisa and the original photographer Marty, just went AWOL and held up the project. Emily and Deni did a great job of finding new volunteers and keeping things on track. The other issue was the problematic interaction with the client. It was often difficult to get sufficient information from the Coro staff, to have them stick with their decisions, or to keep them on track with the top priorities to move the work along. They didn't seem to fully understand the materials they would need to provide, or how Taprooters need to work outside normal business hours on their project. Maybe this could be resolved with a more thorough conversation with the client beforehand?
column42: Emily Hopp, Deni Robey, Jonathan Netek, Braden Summers
column47: I'm not sure how thoroughly Taproot describes its members' work process to each client. In this case, Coro didn't seem to know that we usually work nights and weekends; this complicated timing. Perhaps Taproot could remind clients of this before the work gets underway?

Our Project Manager was wholly lacking in people skills and did not earn the trust and respect of those below her.  In the final stages she contributed so little as to require our Account Director to have to step in and take a much bigger role than he should have had to.
column47: Having a 'toxic personality' on the team made what would have otherwise been a challenging project into an almost unbearable project. column47: I think I underestimated the amount of work that would be necessary to build a Drupal website, especially the theming part. I would recommend that you put together a Taproot Drupal profile that specifies the features that Taproot clients receive and/or limit the scope of features that you will provide in a Drupal integration.

column40: Having a client team that was so organized. Their decision-making process was lean and focused. We helped them make authentic choices, which they were ready to implement. This was gratifying for all of us. In many ways, BCEF showed itself to be an ideal Taproot client.
column41: As usual, we started with five people and ended up a team of three. One exited for maternity leave and another failed to fulfill responsibilities. Even though both people had already worked on numerous Taproot projects, their work for BCEF wasn't thorough--and they didn't seem to care. We all had different quality standards for presenting to the client.    I took over as brand strategist and project manager, which dragged out the research phase and left less time for the designer to complete the logo. She felt aggravated and rushed, then deliberately slowed the process by taking extra vacations. This delayed our client deliverables. She sped up at the project's end, however, enabling the client to make an immediate deadline for their next Taproot grant application.
column47: Please provide better advice to new account directors who have never managed (or been involved in) a Taproot project. They must vet candidates carefully for positions, asking up-front about personal commitments that could impact the project (pregnancies, imminent moves, job search, family responsibilities, etc).   It's basically a hiring decision, so you have to hire the people who are ready, and who will deliver the work. People love to list Taproot on their resumes, but the real volunteers are those who go above and beyond every time. If everyone did that, we would consistently provide high-quality client service, which is what we're here to do.

column40: The most rewarding part of the project is contributing to an organization's research to end HIV. I am also happy to enable volunteers of HRS build a strong message regarding the work they are doing in the global fight against HIV.  This work supports HRS in their long term strategic plan and that opportunity for a non-profit is a significant and something I am happy to contribute to.
column41: The most challenging part was brainstorming names and finding the right one to present to the client. Although the team used the appropriate tools and used a strategic plan for finding names, we were simply off in the names we proposed. It was unfortunate that we could not come to an agreement on that deliverable. The final name that HRS provided, Bridge Research, is great and a perfect fit!
column47: I was so very fortunate to contribute to one non-profit across two service grants. The opportunity to build on the work from the Key Messages campaign for the Naming Campaign was invaluable and I am looking forward to seeing the outcome of the Website project for Bridge Research. This was an experience I will continue to reference in my career and personal life.

column40: That the client felt that the final product exceeded its expectations.
column41: Nothing. If I have to say anything, it would just be that I could have used a little more direction/clarity around copywriting roles/expectations. I anticipated that client would provide first round of copy, and I would edit; but the process was reversed for this particular project. Also, was difficult for me to integrate weekly conference call in my schedule, but feel the calls were useful and necessary.

column40: The most rewarding part was delivering a product that the nonprofit was very happy with and giving them confidence in using it to raise money.
column41: I felt for much of the project, one member of the creative team was taking a lackadaisical approach to their responsibilities as defined by their role and was trying to exert undue creative control over the project. This member tended to be a little rude and aggressive at times, but after some team discussion, we were able to resolve these issues.
column47: The marketing director on our team was not as invested in the project as she was quite busy. She sometimes missed vital meetings and was not engaged with the creative team during production. I think it's important to have someone who ensures that the vision and objectives described in the project brief are fully realized and also invests their marketing expertise into the project. This kind of commitment was missing from this project and I believe it was a cause of some creative conflicts that arose during production.

column47: While working with this nonprofit it seemed to me that they weren't as clear in their branding as I might normally recommend a client be (they wanted to use 2 versions of their logo, each with a different tagline). If nonprofits come to Taproot asking for a specific item, does Taproot assess if that is what they really need? I know that they have pressing needs (to raise money, especially), but just like a for-profit entity, a well-thought-out branding and communication strategy can be beneficial. As well as looking at all the other aspects of a nonprofits' operations. I hope the brochure will help WINGS raise the funds they need, but it feels like there is so much more they may need help with.

column47: Possibly train the project managers how to manage in a way that greatly reduces meetings. For example, one of the founders of BaseCamp, the collaboration board we used on our project, gave a TED talk discussing how tools like this help us eliminate most meetings. I can easily see doing 30 minutes every two weeks with members,rather than an hour each week. It simply requires that the team leader spend a little more time on BaseCamp to ask what people are doing, set deadlines, answer questions, etc. Anyway, I felt that a lot of meeting time is wasted (but my bias is that most of us do too many meetings, which aren't necessarily very productive). Highly recommend checking out the TED talk (Why meetings aren't productive).

column41: 1) Misrepresentation regarding the who exactly was the responsible party for the nonprofit.  2) Blueprint was difficult to follow. It was written at too high of a strategic level to be of value to the nonprofit.
column46: Have brought a number of volunteers into the org.
column47: 1)Mentor program - need Senior AD's to work with new AD's, so you don't burn the new ones out.  2) Update the blueprints - make them clearer, more concise.  Too high level for the size of nonprofits that are being served. While they may, on a market level, be priced as a very high ticket item, the strategic level at which they were designed is too "abstract" for small nonprofits.  What is needed is implementation tools or "How to" processes - at least for the Board recruitment grant.  3) Set up an Advisory board of senior PBC's to provide feedback and get them more involved with the organization.  They are on the front lines of the grants and involved with the day to day operations with both the Taproot offices and the clients.  Each city should have an Advisory board of PBC's and Aaron and ED's should meet with them once a year to gather business intelligence from them.

column40: For myself, having retired and missing the intellectual and social opportunities employment presents, it gave me the opportunity to utilize my skills in an organization that needed my level of expertise and work with a group of dedicated, professional and interesting individuals.
column41: When the project was accepted by Taproot, there was some concern that the the organization lacked a strategic plan and therefore, conducting a Board Recruitment effort might be premature.  Lacking this five-year strategic plan proved problematic throughout the project.  I think that Taproot should have guided the organization to apply for the strategic planning grant instead of the Board Recruitment.  Much of our client meeting time was spent discussing strategic design work because our team had the capability to do that.  But we were constantly aware that our mission and timetable was recruitment based, not strategic based and always had to fall short of spending the necessary time to assist them in understanding and supporting them in making an organizational shift.  That was frustrating to us.
column42: Nancy Mason, Dan Grieber, Phanmaly Somsanith
column47: Alison Farber, my Account Manager, was great to work for and was extremely responsive. The Blueprints, while helpful, are extremely overwhelming.  There is so much information that its difficult, as a newbie, to distinguish the important from the not so important.  I think they need to be looked at with a critical eye. Finally, and probably most importantly, when reading the Blueprints, it appears to be a linear recommended process.  Complete Part 1 and then move to Part 2.  Having been a CEO of a consulting business for many years, I took the blueprint and had my different technical experts working concurrently on many of the sections all at the same time, as long as step 3 was not completely influenced by the completion of step 1.  We were able to complete our project well within the 6 month timeline and provided the client with extra levels of effort due to our planning process.  That might be an area that could be addressed with the Project Directors in future communications.

column41: getting a consensus among team members as to what worked, what didn't. And writing material that everyone could agree upon was another challenge, as most everyone wanted to control the copywriting to a degree. I've been a writer/editor for many years, and I've found that everyone thinks of themselves as a writer ultimately, and people don't know how to give notes well, or direction.
column47: given that I was the copywriter, and we were developing key messaging, most of the responsibility for doing the actual writing fell onto my shoulders, and I would have to complete a good amount of work in a limited timeframe, to meet our deadlines. And of course, everyone considers themselves a wordsmith to some extent, so I would have to explain things very thoroughly so everyone could appreciate how functional my work was, and why I used certain wording, and not others. It's not possible to write by committee, and that was frustrating at times.

column41: Even though I was the writer, I ended up doing the typography on a 40-page annual report. I am still not clear whether the graphic designer/creative director (Max) thought that someone else was going to lay out the type properly, or whether he thought that simply flowing the text into the layout with no paragraph formatting, etc. was good enough. The marketing director and I were quite taken aback by the sloppiness of the type in the first layout and made a number of suggestions; the designer replied that he  didn't know how to make them. Taproot (Alison) kindly found us a graphic designer who was more familiar with InDesign, but she was unable to help us when she discovered that Max had used some Mac fonts and she only had a Windows system. So, although I don't know much about InDesign, I volunteered to fix the type myself. Meghan spent a couple of hours on the phone with me sorting out what to do about various aspects of the typography, and some designer friends where I do parttime work also helped me, so it turned out fine. But the situation never should have occurred in the first place. Perhaps Max misunderstood the duties of the graphic designer on a Taproot project and didn't realize that he would be responsible for the final InDesign file? Anyway, I say all this not to slam Max, who may have simply suffered from a misunderstanding, but rather to make Taproot and its volunteer account directors aware that there might be a disconnect between what they expect and what some graphic designers think they're supposed to do.

Even prior to her becoming ill, there was poor communication and division of responsibilities which hindered progress on the project.  The other thing was around defining the criteria for the onsite interviews.  I felt that, rather than the questions focusing on the skills required for success at ASA, which would have provided us with the material for our final report, we caved to ASA's alterior needs and our questions instead focused on more generic information associated with ASA and their concerns about dissention within their internal team.  I inquired about this a number of times - how the questions that we were asking were applicable to the purpose of our project, how the interviews could be used to collect the information we needed - and was not given a clear answer.

column47: As I understood, it was stressed by Taproot that some clients try to veer projects out of scope and that the team needs to consciously keep the client on track with the approved project.  This subject was discussed within our team a number of times but I felt that we still catered to our client's off-topic needs and it hindered our ability to provide a clear resolution to the approved project.  As well, I feel as though some members of the team were not committed to the timelines or the completion of the project, which set us off track.  I had stated clearly before the start of the project that I was expecting and due around the targeted completion of our project.  I volunteered heavily for work that needed to be done on the front end of the project and felt as though there was a lack of follow up from the team in general but, more specifically, from the project manager.  I felt as though the client was looking for resolution to concerns that were not part of the approved project and that we needed to be more direct about our inability to respond to those concerns so that our focus could be clearly maintained as the approved project.

column47: We would have been done faster and probably better if I had gone in as a team of one along with the account manager. The software configurer came through in the end but was very slow to understand the business need and figure out the software. The Taproot deliverable templates are poorly constructed and hard to use, and really didn't help that much. Taproot either needs to screen for developers who are adept at independent learning, or provide Salesforce training. Even a Salesforce ERD would have been a huge help. I ended up feeling like I was the only team member who understood what needed to be done. It was never clear what the data role on the team was for. The PM was an obstacle. Our developer was a nice man who eventually got it figured out. Our Account Manager Rob Holt was excellent.  When it comes down to it a donor database is no mystery and it's unlikely core requirements will vary much client to client. Taproot should consider combining the PM and BA roles, or the BA/software configurer roles and maybe doing away with the data role. Also, evolutionary prototyping would have been a much more effective approach than the waterfall approach prescribed by Taproot. It's probable that Taproot could even have a core configuration that would meet most of the needs of most clients. All in all, the approach and structure was wasteful and the technical team unprepared.

column41: I honestly felt that the project was not managed well. There was a lot of oversight in the timeline projected in addition to role assignments. Our developer and I both took on the most amount of work by playing multiple roles. I was the Information Architect and Web Designer. Our Web Developer was the Front End and Back End Developer. In our initial kickoff meeting, I strongly recommended that they look for an Information Architect and Front End Developer considering the length of the project. It became apparent that my recommendation had been dismissed.  We did not have the bandwidth to manage both roles under these specific time constraints. In addition to my day job, I burned up to 80-100 hours three weeks into the project.    All of these roles assigned were an integral part of delivering a large scale website. There was simply too much work demanded for the lack of staff and process involved.  But in the end, the client was very pleased with the results.

column41: The most frustrating part of this project was that the Taproot team didn't get much creative discretion on this project.  I'm an experienced graphic designer and presented three great designs, but the client was very specific on what they wanted.  We gave them a great product at the end, but I don't think it's as creative and eye-catching I would have liked.  The client wanted it their way, and I felt that they were taking advantage us with the numerous rounds of revisions.  In the end, we had to do what the client wanted.  That's fine for a paid project, but for a pro bono project, the Taproot team should be able to have more discretion as we're the experts.  There were times in this project where I felt like I was free labor for Brooklyn Kindergarten Society.    Also, this project was way more time-consuming that I expected, mainly because of the rounds of revisions.  The client kept changing copy,  photo preferences, pagination, etc.

I'm looking to expand my web design skills.  Also, a brochure would be great.  For this particular project, I would suggest that as experts, the Taproot team has more discretion rather than just having to do exactly what the client wants.  Also, the clients should be expected to be more organized in terms of getting us appropriate copy and going through edits.  Numerous rounds of edits/revisions for a pro bono project isn't fair for the volunteers.

column41: 1. Taproot's contract is long and wordy and required a significant amount of time to read over and revise.  2. The Gantt format schedule is an inefficient method to share scheduling with other members of the team. A simple chronological and itemized list is an easy format to share in Google Doc with team members.  3. The web designer that was originally hired to complete the layout and site navigation for the site was not skilled enough to deal with the parameters and constraints of the web. This caused the whole team to reassess roles and tasks costing us unnecessary time to both ourselves and our client.
column42: Tina Liao, Audrey Kuhner, Christina Rimmer
column46: I'm tepid about recommending this organization: I would like to see the following improved: 1. Taproot contract process, 2. Scheduling system, 3. The hiring of web designers
column47: + The Taproot process for teams should accommodate the use of Google Docs: it allows teams to collaborate efficiently synchronously and asynchronously. This means: 1. making sure team members have a Google user account; 2. making sure that the Taproot contract is in a simple format where styles are kept to the bare minimum (its current state is excessively designed, and inconsistently rendered across different applications); 3. Using a scheduling system that is a list-itemized format (not the Gantt format).  + Dealing with the clients webhosting service, Earthlink, was unnecessarily time consuming. I strongly recommend that Taproot begin research on how to get clients to host with reliable and more cost-efficient services. I would suggest Taproot looking into helping clients move their website services to WordPress.com for both hosting and framework: its free and very reliable.
