column47: Sample of communication from the Project Manager and to the Account Director on this project regarding focusing on the common good.  Re: reminder, check point call today From: kristin rutland <kristin.rutland@yahoo.com> View Contact  To: mark@gianturco.com     --------------------------------------------------------------------------------  Mark   I understand from last night's call with the BHNV client that they are satisfied with the work - that is ahead of schedule - performed to date  from the Team.  I also appreciated the fact that you and Kandace Evelyn have continuously expressed your thanks to the team for their volunteer efforts.     I am happy that I was able to extend my contributions beyond the delivery of the requirements brief and to set-up a repeatable way to scrub/clean data in MS Access that the team, including the Project Manager, could quickly could re-use.  Based on last night's call, I understand that the selected development resources will now be taking on these efforts to assist in data clean-up with MS Access for all aspects of the implementation.   Consequently, I am little concerned with the Project Managers' communications regarding unfinished development work. I have discussed these concerns to Prab.  This has not been resolved to my satisfactoin.    Could you please confirm your expectations for any continuing business analysis deliverables to wrap up this engagement?      I do not want any requirements validation work to be overlooked.  I understand that there may be some User Acceptance Testing work that perhaps I should be thinking about with the client.  It has not yet been discussed.  I am happy to take the lead on these discussions.   Thank you,   Kristin     --- On Tue, 10/19/10, Prabhakar Bhogaraju <prabhakar_bhogaraju@yahoo.com> wrote:   From: Prabhakar Bhogaraju <prabhakar_bhogaraju@yahoo.com> Subject: Re: reminder, check point call today To: "kristin rutland" <kristin.rutland@yahoo.com> Date: Tuesday, October 19, 2010, 7:10 PM   Kristin -   You had been looking at data migration activities for two areas:  accounts & contacts.  I will look to Cindi to lead Households & Donations.  That should keep things in a 50-50 split somewhat.   On the areas of your focus:  You had a couple of good starting point contributions.  It would be nice to have you continue to lead and see them till they are complete.  I think the accounts data import template needs work to accomodate grants (grant type, grant comments, grant staff etc.,).  I see contact template needing some household information to capture.    I sense apprehension on your part to do hands-on development, in terms of  MS Access queries.  That is OK, I will pitch in  as much as I can.  you mention scrubbing, nope, we should not.  In an earlier meeting you suggested we not scrub and I am holding to that principle.  So, no scrubbing asked of you either.   In short, can you can complete the template work for the two tables you started?  And beyond the template work, can you help with the testing side of things?  BHNV's testing will be the principal activity.  But testing the data/relationships and reports based on your past experience will be very helpful in delivering a quality product.   Open to your suggestions.    thank you, -P

column41: There was an internal power struggle within AWS that led to the ousting of their Executive Director.  That conflict affected all the work we did from design to copy.  We often found ourselves inexplicably pulled in several different directions by the client and although our Account Director Chloe was masterful in creating a buffer for us, you can only do so much.  Although AWS signed off many times on portions of the project as final, they continued to revisit them with changes through the entire process.  Several times during our weekly team meetings, it became apparent to us that we were being listened in on by some additional party.  AWS was the only one besides us that had both phone number and password to our conference call.  This became so awkward for us that we eventually changed to a new number to assure our privacy.   For me, a client exhibiting this kind of behavior was a first.

column40: The realization that our analysis could severely impact the lives of teenagers F&O currently serves. Not for Profits have highly educated, smart people running the organizations, but in this case, they did not understand the project.

column41: For a web project of this scope (the LAGLC website included 300+ pages and deep features, such as calendars, CMS, publishing workflows, permissions systems, etc.), Taproot's blueprint just doesn't work. Three reasons:  1. Outdated Processes and Scope of Requirements Few websites can afford to be static these days; websites are living, breathing publishing platforms that often scale to include dynamic data, web services, syndication channels, content management systems, and user accounts. I was surprised that Taproot's scope for advanced websites basically treated the deliverables as a handful of static html pages. Really? This isn't 1999. Few nonprofits (or any org, for that matter) will benefit from having a static "brochure" site that can't grow. Most will agree: a CMS is a minimum-ante these days.  FACT: websites are software: they are complex, data-rich, and MUST be scalable.  2. Wrong Project Management Methodology The Taproot blueprint used a "waterfall"style of project management  as opposed to "agile" project management, which would have been far more appropriate. "Waterfall" management (gant charts, a linear progression of phases and responsibilities, client input only in beginning and end) is far too rigid and "front-loaded" with planning to work successfully for larger scopes. Large systems NEVER develop according to plan. Inevitably, large projects reveal new requirements midstream, or impart new knowledge / insights as development is happening. There are too many contingencies, too many midstream changes, too many decisions to be made at every milestone. That's why an "Agile" methodology is how today's software teams manage themselves to avoid failure: they work *iteratively* and involve the client in a close, constant feedback loop.  3. Too Much Paperwork and too many documents to track and version. The taproot blueprint, as well as the vast majority of team communications required an endless back-and-forth of files and document versions. It's unmanageable and extremely inefficient to track multiple doc versions / variants in email attachments and manually collate and merge them every week. It would be MUCH more efficient (and green) to go entirely paperless and cloud-based via GoogleDocs (or something similar), where ONE copy of each timeline and planning doc is centrally stored and simultaneously editable by multiple authors.
column47: The team structure for this project could also be improved. For instance, the marketing role virtually "fell off" one third of the way into the blueprint. After the initial discovery / marketing recommendation phases, our marketing person literally didn't need to be involved anymore. Why not dismiss her from the project so she can work on another? On the other hand, we could have benefited from having one more development resource. I ended up working at least triple the hours estimated by Taproot because I was doing extra duty as a web developer.  Also  It will be wise to talk to industry thought leaders about how to successfully plan and execute today's large-scale web projects. I suggest talking to interactive and software shops in particular; NOT ad agencies (ad agencies deliver Flashy marketing one-off sites, but not long-term web publishing platforms).  We had to flex the project management style and process a bit on this assignment in order to make it work for our huge scope. Over time, we came up with some efficient practices that might be beneficial for Taproot's blueprint. I've built several large-scale Drupal, Magento, and custom Wordpress sites, so I'll be happy to share some tips  So, if you'd like to discuss any of these points in more detail, reach out anytime.

column41: Where do I start!  The Account Director was the most frustrating part of the entire project.  From the start, he was not engaged and hands-off the project.  I understand that it is a management philosophy, and that is fine if you empower your team to do their work and then stand back.  But, he did not.  From the start, he provided us incomplete information.  He did not seek out information and just sat there, not saying a single word, during the first three client meetings.  He provided no guidance - strategic, tactical, or organizational - during the entire project.  He did not keep us in the loop of his conversations with the client - never. We had weekly working sessions (of several hours each) for the first two months, and he never attended those nor followed up on progress.  He never got our questions answered.  He did not answer emails about coming to client meetings or our internal meetings, or addressed concerns when they were raised over email.    It all became unbearable when our initial designer quit a day before a major client meeting and milestone, and he told us to lie to the client - to tell the client that our designer is out sick, and that we would still deliver the promised designs within 4 days.  Right after the meeting, I wrote in an email that I do not lie to clients and I am not willing to be put in this kinds of situations.  Others followed.  He said that we were making a big deal out of nothing and left it at that.  When he found a new designer, she was not pulling her weight and not answering emails or committing to things.  This really made that phase of the process difficult and created a lot of frustrations for the entire team. We all voiced our frustrations over emails (we did not have any calls for several months, which is very usual in my experience).  He finally offered to speak to me over the phone (I don't know if he did the same with others), and I voiced my frustrations to him in an hour long call.  Then nothing happened.  Frustrations between the group members mounted (all over email).  We all ended the project not speaking to each other.  To add to the problems with the Account Director, our project manager lacked basic understanding and skills to manage the project.  During the first phase, where I was driving the discovery and strategy part, I drove the process and was very clear on what we had to do.  I organized the meetings, I drove the agenda and I included everyone in the decision making (although the Acct Director abstained from all of that).  But things really fell apart when my phase ended, and the website went into design and production - a phase where the project manager had to drive the process.  We did not hold weekly meetings.  There was no task follow up. Communication was just over email, where it is extremely easy to misinterpret things.  The new designer "checked out" of the project before she even checked in.  The copywriter was lost in terms of what her role was in the project (an issue raised many, many times by her and me and never addressed).  And I was frustrated because I could not do anything since there was an Acct Director and a project manager on the team.    Overall, this project was one of the most, if not the most, frustrating working experience I've had in my 13 years in the business.  It is really sad that I came in with a lot of enthusiasm to help the client, but left with full hate (and I don't use this word loosely) for this project.  Team management is crucial

column41: In my opinion, there were simply too many people involved in producing this brochure.  It should have been a very simple project, however in some ways, I felt that the Taproot processes and protocols actually got in the way of efficiency in completing this project.  In my opinion, for a project this small, there were one too many account people involved. Also, I felt that the client was not managed in a very efficient way.  At the end of the project, some people were experiencing burnout, and not really willing to go the extra couple of yards to convince the client that their message could be clearer.  It was frustrating to be so close, and then have people on the team just sort of throw up their hands and say "well, let's just do it this way, because I've spent enough time on this already."  I, for one, was willing to go a lot further, including meetings, revises, etc, to assure the job was done right.
column43: Laurie Hughes, Thomas Phillip, Jacuqui Genow
column47: I strongly support Taproot's mission of helping non-profits.  And I am looking forward to helping again in the future.  However, I think that Taproot should take a serious look at streamlining the structure, procedures, and protocols of its teams according to the scope and complexity of the project.  In the case of a creating or revamping a website, it would probably make sense to have 3 account people on the team.  However for a simple print brochure like the one for which I wrote the copy, the layers of protocol and procedure actually got in the way.  In addition, our Account Supervisor was virtually missing in action for about 70% of the project due to family issues.   To be fair to the team and project, I think she should have made Taproot aware of the lack of time she could devote to the project, so her responsibilities should have been reassigned to another Acct Sup, or even better, to the Account Executive.  Another frustration was that near the end of the project, the art director got extremely busy at work, and several times failed to make copy changes in an accurate or timely way, causing the rest of the team to do extra work to clear up the confusion.  I cannot say enough about Tommy Humphreys. His professionalism helped to keep it all light and as upbeat as possible.

column41: I joined the team mid-way through the project and found the design and architecture already completed. It turned out that these pieces were not well thought through and they don't meet the clients needs 100%. The design is...not good, which is disappointing. It was frustrating to have to work within the constraints of the architecture such as it was. After this experience, I will likely decline to join projects mid-way through completion.

First there was this power struggle between the original account director and PM (this PM later became the new account director). Secondly the project was poorly managed, we lost the Business Analyst at the beginning of this project, and the PM thought she can fulfill that role (Big Mistake), and there's no regular project meeting/call, everything was pretty much based on the availability of the PM, which is  why this project took almost one and half year. I think Taproot foundation was also responsible for the delay, someone should have stepped in during the power struggle and contacted all team members for their feedback but nobody did.

column41: Initial staffing was challenging due to west suburban location. Then had 2 of 5 team members drop out -- one being the proj. mgr who was new to Taproot and I think not clear on the process and expectations even though I was also new and felt it was all pretty straightforward. Good news in that case was she dropped out early and I was willing to accept the add'l responsibility as part of my learning curve though I consider it unlikely that I would have found another PM in a hurry. Second member may have been well-intentioned but apparently was over-committed in terms of her time and in her case, bailed very late and at a critical point in the process. In both cases, tough to recruit replacements once a project is up and running. Perhaps Taproot should consider having some "reserve players" for each wave of projects -- folks who volunteer to be available for just about anything in the event a team loses someone. A list which they maintain and provide to ADs looking for some help. Taproot was somewhat helpful in attempting to support our need to find replacements but that additional burden falls on the shoulders of the AD which isn't exactly fair under the circumsnaces.
column42: all -- Jean Skornicka, Laura Miller, Julia Winn (NOTE: should also have a "would be okay" category here)
column47: See some notes above. Overall, will definitely do it again, was a great experience, Taproot sets up a great approach to the challenges. While this project suffered a few staff issues, the quality of both our core team and the client's made it manageable and (relatively) painless. Can imagine, however, that the line between success and disaster is a thin one -- based not just on quality of the work but team interaction and chemistry not to mention commitment to contribution -- and this applies to Taproot team as well as client's!   One small(er) thing to mention, probably more a personal perspective than anything else... As the AD who also (willingly) assumed the role of PM, I was very close to the process and because the team was open to my hands-on participation in the work product, I felt a strong sense of "ownership" of the work product. And thus very proud to be serving it up to the client. But can't imagine playing the AD role as arm's-length as might be suggested by Taproot's definition of the role. Have been warned that it's a good idea during the staffing process to indicate a tendency toward a higher level of participation so as to insure at least the PM is not offended, but that's a tough thing. Sorry, no immediate ideas on how to change this, necessarily, but perhaps should be strongly emphasized in the AD and PM training you do. Or perhaps ADs and PMs should be able to access each others profiles where comments like this could be served up about ourselves, etc.?  All in all, as mentioned, will do this again. Feel like the process is at least 80-90% right with uncontrollable, unpredictable "human factors" making up the balance -- so probably about as good as it can be!

column47: -May want to revisit the project template since the discovery work should include deeper competitive review for unique positioning.   -Also, should definitely add a professional trainer and perhaps add role-plays for the training component.  None of the core team members truly understood L&D training and adult learning principles to develop and lead a truly effective training session.  I brought in a friend/professional to develop and lead that part for us.  - Avoid goverment-related non-profits like a state university since they are truly too complex from a key msg and branding standpoint (and hence the stepping stone for further grants).  I would never do that again. - I was really pleased with the team I pulled together. Each had their own strengths and although it was touch and go at times, everyone did their job, and did it well. -I really love the concept of - and have talked about this since - using only core strengths to build a team. When a gap became clear, I added an expert to fill that gap (twice).  Interesting to consider from an HR perspective on the for-profit side!

column41: The team was very varied in their experience on launching a site, and it was extremely difficult to get everyone on the same page. It might have been easier reining in a diverse team if the project manager had experience in Web. She worked hard and was great to work with, but I think her lack of understanding of the process and technical aspects was a challenge. We had many people leave and join the project, which kept things from being cohesive. And we had one polarizing team member, the developer, who was extremely difficult to communicate and work with. We didn't meet regularly because of issues with travel and scheduling, which didn't help our communications troubles. Especially as the project dragged on, it was difficult to stay motivated. Frankly, I'm relieved it's over.
column46: I wouldn't recommend it based on my experience
column47: It's so difficult to get a team of strangers working well together remotely. If there had been more face time and clearer expectations of each member, I think we might have had more success.

column40: Working with the client was the most rewarding. They are very passionate about their org, very professional, but also easy to work with. They appreciated the hard work the team put into the project.
column41: Team was frustrating at times. There were some team issues that made the process very difficult specifically working with the writer Jessica Hagy. Jessica is a talented writer but I don't believe the Taproot process is right for her. She's not a team oriented person. She was not considerate of other peoples time and the project schedule, she missed a number of team phone meetings, she would not respond to emails and phone calls at crucial times during the project.

column40: Being able to provide a needed service to a worthy nonprofit  that couldn't afford it otherwise.
column41: Poorly defined role as the project copy editor/writer. Lack of clear direction on processes when it came to actually developing and revising online content. Not able to input my own copy corrections to content once it was online; inability to communicate clearly about how to get corrections made.

column40: Some of the board members and employees completely understood the concepts and work put into the project.
column41: "Do not look a gift horse in the mouth"     The project cost the non-profit nothing. It was explained that the team working on it are professionals and they do this for a living. Too many times pro bono clients doubt what they are presented and want to see more (free work). Then they will try to manipulate what you have presented (for free) because they do not understand the strategy and work that goes into it.   The client is not an art director, they usually know nothing about design and design strategy. EXPLAIN this to the non-profit client, let them know not to make an fool of themselves.  Time lines-the team has their personal lives, jobs and other interests. Having to return three, four or five times to present the design and strategy is a nuisance and ends up costing the team money and time for their own clients, projects and personal events.  Create a work book explaining these issues to the non-profit client and Board of Directors. Have  them read, understand and sign it.
column42: Sonja Brisson, Jeff Idler, Maneesha Lall
column47: The importance of quality printing and consistent use of of the specified paper stock. Using cheesy stock can kill your design or brand faster than you can say: glossy stock, linen paper and thermography.

This is partly due to our limitations of scope, ut also due to finally having to just get it done to the best of the programmer's capabilties.  The project took much more of my time than expected because I had to continually track down resources and QA and shepherd the project (to an extensive degree).

column40: The most rewarding part was seeing the impact that our project had on Pathways.  It was amazing to see the annual report come together.  Our final product was such an imporvement over what Pathways had used in the past and we could tell that they were excited to use this new document to fundraise.
column41: It was difficult at times to get the client to focus on one message.  There were different groups within Pathways that wanted different messages conveyed and wanted to use the document for different purposes. As a result, there was some miscommunication initially and we were told conflicting things by members of Pathways.  The other frustrating this was the timing of our meetings.  Most of my team works on a freelance basis, so many of the meeting were scheduled during the middle of the day when they had time.  This was a bit difficult for me since I have a very standard office job.
column47: I though the project was a great experience for me personally. It was really interesting to work with people outside of the finance industry (my profession) and to learn about Pathways.  We had a great team at Pathways and they made the process an easy one.  I also have a much better idea of my role and will be able to take a more proactive role on my future Taproot projects.

column40: I helped out in my community.
column41: Taproots blueprint and timeline were unrealistic and did not corelate to real world proceedures or expectations.
column46: Given the lack of professional skills and experience from some of my fellow volunteers, I would not recomend Taproot untill they found a better way to screen volunteers with appropriate experience and skills for their roles.
column47: I felt the screening criteria and procedure for Taproots grant recipients need to be revised or updated. I felt the client I worked on didn't really need our services and there are more needy organizations out there that could have been better served by our contributions. I felt the client didn't really need a new website designed and could very well afford a designer and programmer to do one.  The scope for the Advanced Website seems unrealistic by not providing a finished product and expecting the client to finish it themselves. If the client had an in-house programmer,then this procedure is reasonable, but which of these clients would have an in-house programmer. If they did, I don't think they need our services, which brings me to my first point.  The Blueprint timeline is unrealistic in that it doesn't provide proper time for client review and any subsequent revisions and review.  As I stated earlier, Taproot needs to have a better way to vet out their volunteers. Three of my co-volunteers didn't have the appropriate experience and skills for their positions which makes my job a lot harder and less pleasurable. It also has a negative effect on the final product and the overall image of Taproot.

column40: Finally completing the advance website project.

column41: Client changes and delays on review of the brochure in development. This project started in July 2009 and final client approval was received about early Sep 2010. I'm unemployed so this timeline was not a particular burden for me but other team members faced time conflicts. As a result, two team members changed.
column47: Brochure blueprint template was not complete. Team added a timeline for team initial draft review.  TP should advise clients to be responsive to project timelines. This makes not only business sense (yes I know we're working with non profits) it also respects the volunteers' time. If a grade were assigned for client responsiveness and timeliness I'd give a C to CCNB.

column40: I greatly enjoyed working with the clients and training them to use their new website. I felt like I created a site that not only met their current needs, but would grow with them in the future.
column41: At some points, I wished I had another technically proficient team member. At times it would have been nice to collaborate with my team members while doing development, but not even the designer had any experience with coding websites.
column47: My recommendation would be to expand the development time needed for advanced websites. Most advanced websites today must be built using content management systems, which often require a lot of time to set up. I would also recommend that two developers be considered for large adv. websites, one more for front-end coding and one for more back-end programming. A designer who can do front-end coding would also be a help. If I had not had a very flexible freelance schedule during development, I would not have been able to finish the work anywhere near the deadline.

Teams are coming up with excellent deliverables and Taproots resource database is very limited.  Taproots could log all project deliverables and start posting best practices, sample forms, sample presentations, etc and continue to improve upon resources available to Pro Bono Consultants.  It might be best to have a SME in each Taproots area to better assess the quality and best practices for each.

(In fairness a personal situation took the leader away from the project for several months). Some of those on the team were more interested in showing the others how smart, experienced and right they were than in meeting the needs of the client.

column47: I really enjoyed the process and gained a lot from it. I feel we were fortunate in having a really cooperative and switched-on client. They were also lovely people, which helps a lot. I think it would be useful to have guidelines for agreeing what goes on each page of the report. This was not covered in the Requirements Brief. I led this but it wasn't clear who should have authority to finalise this decision and there was no deadline for when this should be agreed. I think it would be useful to have a form to complete and sign off. Also, I had understood there would be a limit to the number of copy changes a client could make and that one specific person would be responsible for determining these changes on the client side. This was not the case for our project and I felt time and resources could have been saved if it had been the case. That said, it was an excellent project and all members of both the client team and our team were fantastic to work with.

column40: The problems of Oakland and its youth are in the news everyday. To know in depth of such an organization that cares and motivates was an eyeopener to say the least.   The client, the actual executive team , is the force behind it all.
column41: What is frustrating to see is that YU, the executive team,is missing a few key elements that impacts their progress to reach more measurable results.  The caliber of the board members recruited are for political measures more than for actual functionality.   Now as far as the team, the AM took the bull by the horn unnecessarily and was flying solo most of the time. The competitive report was eliminated, the marketing part was deemed unnecessary. And I had to insist on adding my two cents worth in the report about the value of branding, how it can help them better  recruit and what do they need to do. It was very well received and appreciated from YU . That in itself  was my self validation  that i was on the right track, and my professional  "gut"expertise is still alert. I was glad I stuck to my conviction.

column41: Lack of project management; indeterminate scope for quick fixes (would have liked more examples) as our scope spun out of control a little

column40: I like the client and believe in their mission. They have invited me to serve on their board and I look forward to it.
column41: The phone calls took way too long compared to my last project. Laborious phone calls up to two hours long.   The art director was a no-show on the day of our first draft presentation and never really explained why. I had to present using black and white web print outs off the web instead of finished comps.   Copy comments from the team came in dribs and drabs, and people who had already given their notes commented a second and third time, on the same draft. I was getting internal changes from one team member the night before the piece was due, putting them in stickies on the pdf and sending back to the art director at 1 am. I asked her to send me back the deck for proofing one more time, but she didn't, possibly due to the late hour, and we ended up giving the client a finished product with a typo in it. Fortunately, their board had further changes, which the art director and I did after the project closed, so we were able to fix the typo.
column46: This was definitely a lot bumpier than my last Taproot experience. Under Jean Luc Lamirande on Girls' Inc., our team really geled. There was a clear understanding of the division of labor, and people were supportive of each other and respectful of each other's skills. This project was a bumpier ride. There were personality issues and professionalism issues (not showing up for the presentation when you are the person bringing the comp).
column47: This was a stressful project for me personally because of events in my personal life. There was a bit of a culture clash between the people with advertising agency backgrounds and those coming from the client side, in terms of the process and the division of labor. I personally could have been more diplomatic about voicing my frustrations and have learned from this experience.  I think this project could have run more smoothly had the account director not weighed in on copy at the very last minute. A deadline for internal copy comments needs to be set and adhered to so mistakes don't get made.   I also think it might make more sense to schedule an additional presentation to the client between the first and last so they have something to take to their board. The board had a ton of changes after our project was officially closed,  and the art director and I completed the piece.  In some ways, I feel like meeting the schedule became more important than obtaining client buy-in. To be fair, this client did tend to drag their feet and had to be repeatedly prodded to respond. From my standpoint, better to finish a couple weeks later and have client approval on a finished piece than to meet the pre-planned deadline and have to work on the piece after Taproot's involvement has officially ended.

column47: My first Taproot project team was made up of experienced professionals.  Deliverables were high quality and people delivered on time.  This project had more junior people on it.  The finance person had no clue what to do so we did her work for her.  The marketing director was ineffective and the requirements brief was of poor quality; the copywriter basically did her job.  It was difficult getting some people to keep their time commitments.   I know that Taproots is marketing itself as a career-builder. That carries the risk that your teams will not be of true professional quality, which I consider to be one of the strengths of your organization.  If you continue to market to junior level people then I recommend you adjust your support model.

column41: Client delays in providing needed information (financials).

column40: Developing a relationship with my contact person.  Talking to her to really gain an understanding of what was important to the school, and what they were trying to communicate visually.

column47: I just relocated back to the Seattle area, and am sad that Taproot is no longer here.

column40: Working with the client.

column40: For me, the best part was using my skills in executive recruiting to help my fellow consultants understand how to develop recruitment strategy and help the client understand how to successfully recruit at this level.

column47: Strongly recommend: (1) Cut down the size of the projects so run time is closer to 3 - 4 months which will lead to happier volunteers and clients (2) Organize blueprints into three categories (small , med, large) to better meet the needs of all NPOs (one size does not fit all) (3) Streamline blueprints so both teams actually read them and can more easily process and act on

column41: The Taproot team. Only two of the original five were on the final team (me and the AD). column43: Amy Bojanowski, unfortunately if she didn't agree with the graphic designers photo selection, she would go to the client with her concerns. column47: In my experience as a production manager in Advertising, the client might know who the rest of my team was, but they didn't have direct access. I believe the whole team should go to the client meetings, but all client information should come back to just the AE & PM and we should then filter the info to the appropriate team member.

column42: Sol Mesz, Kate Clarkson, Lesley McCave (in an instant!)
column43: George Truong (a very nice guy, but not communicative in a way needed for Taproot Projects)
column47: I thoroughly enjoyed my experience as Project Manager for the Santa Monica Bay Restoration Commission.  I met some incredible professionals (both Team and Client)all dedicated to producing the best product possible.  Despite some misunderstandings with my main client contact regarding just how the Taproot consultancy worked (all volunteer, hence certain unintended delays and some small challenges with meeting logistics), all ended well. For our final closing party, our team will be part of the SMBRC "Heal the Bay/Coastal Cleanup Day" on September 25th in Marina del Rey. Perhaps orientation meetings could get into some greater detail on the importance of understanding how the Taproot system works.  Clients need to know upfront it is entirely volunteer and a collaborative effort,and that there is nothing "one-sided" about the relationship.  For Team members it might be helpful to stress that it is not a "failure" to let the Account Director or PM know early, rather than later in a project that, because of work or personal obligations, continuing is impossible. While project withdrawal obviously CANNOT be a pattern for volunteers, every one deserves a second chance if their schedule is truly compromised.  This way, Taproot will not loose qualified volunteers, and project time lines will be less impacted.

column40: I really enjoyed being able to help a non-profit with a worthy mission to grow. column41: The most difficult part as a PM is maintaining the focus, engery and commitment of the team over the project duration. You have to manage the reality that you are at best second priority to regular work commitments and be aware that conflicts will arise.
column47: 1) I was lucky to have a great team with strong consulting skills, including Michael Nisiotis (AD), and consultants Hari Krishnaswami, Crystal Tsai, and Karin Pavolvic. I must acknowledge the commitment and effort put in by Karin Pavlovic: we would not have been able to keep the project on schedule without her dedication. She would be a great asset to any team, and I would be happy to work with any of them again. I would note that among the team, Crystal had the most frequent conflicts that affected her ability to contribute to the work product.  2) My client, Hour Children, had completed other Taproot service grants. It would have been useful to have access to the work product or team members that had worked on these past projects. This insight would have helped our team to have a more effective relationship with the client faster. I would suggest that for repeat clients, some sort of debriefing access be incorporated in the process, perhaps at the initial scoping phase of the project conducted by the AD. I would think that repeat clients would expect teams to have this knowledge and teams would benefit from the opportunity to leverage the institutional learning that is currently captive and unharnessed within Taproot.

column41: I know our program manager is well aware that as a higher education client, HEI didn't always fit into the Taproot model, and the client wasn't always familiar with how to work with volunteers. The time delays were inevitable but also frustrating. I was also frustrated with the early timing of client meetings -- for those of us who work full-time, 5 p.m. is early for an after-work meeting, and with many team members out of work, I sometimes (and ironically) felt a lack of sensitivity to those of us who have full-time jobs.
column47: I'm repeating a point I made in my response to Question #8 -- over the years, my Taproot projects have had a growing number of unemployed members. I've very sympathetic to their situation (and have been in it), but for three projects now, I have had to push back against teams that wanted to meet during work hours. I do think it needs to be clearer to account directors that the Taproot model presumes that many/most team members are working and have limited availability during daytime hours.   My other comment (reiterating #7) is that Nina Gerwin was a fantastic account director. My issues with meeting timing aside, she was smart, strategic, and 110% committed to the success of the project. We all played a role in the project's success, but without Nina, I don't think we would have succeeded half as well.   And as always, a privilege to volunteer with Taproot!

column40: I was able to learn about an amazing non-profit -- the Variety Boys and Girls Club -- and was truly inspired by the dedication of its staff and the organization's mission. It is a highly effective non-profit that moves mountains. I will continue to support them, as I am now a true believer in what is possible when people care enough to create a viable community and run a tight ship. Additionally, I enjoyed writing the pages, and the creative stimulation of working with other people to provide a useful tool for an effective organization.
column41: The negatives would be: 1. Our project dragged on for 10 months because our web developer took on 2 other projects for Taproot simultaneously with our project, and she got a full-time job in the meantime. We need to do a better job -- all of we members of Taproot -- of recruiting more web developers so that this doesn't happen again. 2. The project manager did not manage our time as efficiently as I would have liked. I would have preferred fewer in-person meetings and a PM with a more direct communication style. 3. The Account Director ran the operation as though he was our CEO, not as a co-collaborator who respects the expertise each member brings to a different area. Although the resulting project was impressive, I think a lot of time could have been saved by simply listening to what Variety wanted at the get-go as well as the thoughts of other team members, who attempted to relay to him the organization's needs.
column47: Overall the experience was positive. Although the PM and AD had a different work style from what I would have preferred, I recognize that they meant well and I appreciate that they were reliable, following the delayed project through until the end.

column47: I think our Account Manager did an amazing job of keeping the team and the client on track - particularly difficult because client's attention to the task was poor and the project management was less than I had hoped.    Frankly I took too long in the discovery process which put a lot of pressure on our writing and graphics people. The client's goal is honorable, their work is good, the community they help needs their work, but the story they originally wanted to tell was impossible to tell.  We spent a lot of time (too much) unraveling it. There needs to be some way to bring the writer into the discovery process early as she had to redo/revise many interviews with key informants so that we could produce the report.   I think if the project manager had been more assertive, then we could have kept to our goals better; certain it would have helped me realize I was taking too long with my portion of the project.  Likewise, a lack of rapport between the client and the project manager meant that they didn't keep to their deadlines either.   The Graphic Designer/Photographer, Copywriter, and the Financial Analyst did great work and made this project a success.  I would happy work with them all, esp. the Financial Analysis and Graphic Designer, again. They're going to be great assets to Taproot and our clients.  All my criticism aside, I feel the client is in a much better position today than they were when we started.  Taproot delivered what the client needed, and I think they'll be one of DC's best non-profits someday.

column41: The project moved very slowly. The biggest reason for this was largely outside anyone's control, as the client was changing server vendors during the project. I do not know what degree it may have additionally been slowed by the client as well (see #11 below).
column47: The client went out of scope with some of their requests or changed plans after the point at which it was really appropriate to do so. I think clients navigating this process for the first time have a hard time looking ahead and anticipating how the project will develop, so needs and problems arise unexpectedly and throw the project off schedule or complicate the deliverables. This happened to some degree in both of the two projects I've done so far. It's possible to overcome these challenges, but if there's anything that can be done to improve client understanding or commitment to the blueprint at the earlier planning stages it would be helpful.

column47: I feel that the Taproot process for annual reports isn't quite right. I think that there is too big of a leap from the SWOT to the first creative concepts. Most annual reports are  unique, and develop their own distinct message/look that goes beyond the corporate branding. It was challenging to begin with the simplicity of the corporate branding elements while trying to elevate the brochure to something greater - and simultaneously adapting the marketing information. It felt like a huge task that was so open-ended because there was very little discussion of the look and feel of the annual report - since all of the time was taken up by creating/correcting the SWOT. The writer didn't know how to brainstrom - so it was a struggle.

column40: Not really sure yet.  Perhaps I need a longer period to reflect on this project.  It was quite challenging on various fronts.  That being said, I really enjoyed working with our Taproot volunteer team, and I value each person's contribution to the project.
column41: This project was littered with challenges from the get-go -- account staffing, client challenges, communications issues, lack of consensus on organizational direction, etc.  Our Taproot team endured multiple staffing changes on the client side and within our account team.  Without the ability to establish and grow our connection and relationship with the client, it was very difficult to service SCOPE to the best of our ability. It6's just like anything in business -- you get out what you put it.  Moving forward, if nonprofit clients aren't willing to commit to and follow through with the resources necessary for a respective service grant, these organizations should not participate in the Taproot process.
column42: I would work with the top three teammates again -- Linda Soldatos, John Allebrand, Kinnari Desai.  They all were very professional.

column47: Major key learning: The way in which an organization values and treats its volunteers speaks volumes about said organization. column47: I have no problem with Taproot. I think you all are doing a great thing here. I got kind of burnt on this project. If I'm going to volunteer my free time to use on non-profit work rather than spend with my family, I'd like for there to be a little more return on my investment. Consequently, I won't be doing another one of these projects for a while. I'm not saying I'll never do another one, but I'm going to have to forget about the frustration from this one before I sign up for another one.

Because we met on the phone, it was easy for certain people to not participate (even when asked) and hide.
column47: The strategic planning prep projects are not very well defined in the blueprint materials.  This might sound strange since there is A LOT of information in there, but I think that there is too much information.  I appreciate the templates and the blueprint, but the information was overwhelming at first and hard to prioritize.  Once we figured it out, we were fine, but it took a while to figure out!  Also, I think that the project manager role is extremely time consuming.  I was experiencing a lull at work so I had plenty of time to dedicate to this project, but I'm not sure how I would have managed if that hadn't been the case.  It was definitely more than 5 hours per week.

column40: Helping guide a team that had never worked on this type of project before.
column41: The process for staffing the project was haphazard and resulted in some rather significant problems for the team (database access for PM's was limited, PM selected was reluctant to take on the role but due to lack of options, was assigned anyway and ended up quitting), client had SIGNIFICANT leadership issues and changes in personnel throughout the project--and the team was left wondering if they were even going to use any of the work we did (other than to let the HR coordinator go). The CEO who applied for the grant didn't see the project through to its conclusion and did not attend the final project delivery meeting.  The succeeding CEO installed a personal friend in the HR role and neither of them seemed to be more than superficially interested in the final report. They didn't want any quick fixes from us. Rather un-satisfying conclusion.

column40: Working with my team, once it was reduced to three people when the marketing manager had to drop out.  It was much easier to juggle three schedules vs. four.
column41: The client was often unresponsive and slow to move on requests.  I didn't feel they recognized the caliber of the team assigned to them or made a real effort to strategically interact with us.  I think Taproot needs to better educate clients about what's involved in a grant.  I also feel it's unrealistic to promise a new brand strategy for a client based on Taproot's very streamlined process and focus on internal interviews.  We expanded the scope to include external focus groups--and would never have come up with viable recommendations for this client without that step.  It may not be realistic for many of your projects, though, so I think you should be very careful in holding out brand strategy as a Taproot deliverable.
column46: I probably would to a less experienced colleague who wants to build/enhance existing skills.
column47: I feel very strongly that you need to be careful about your branding strategy assignments.  You might want to distinguish also between a messaging assignment and a branding assignment.  For an organization whose communications are very poor, the Taproot process would work well.  For an organization that's being buffeted by external market dynamics, this process is too streamlined to be meaningful in my opinion.

Since the client already had a defined marketing strategy in place, the Marketing Manager felt that she was not able to contribute much to the project.  It might be a good idea to recruit people with experience as a business analyst for that role. It will be more valuable the recruit as well as the client. The recruit feel that they can contribute towards the success of the project and the client will get someone with more relevant experience.

column41: As with my first Taproot project, I found the project management to be lacking. Our account director (?) was on her first Taproot project, so was not familiar with processes and pitfalls. I also personally felt our team was not providing enough depth of deliverables to our client given the shift in focus. We went from a Brand Strategy approach to an Operational Strategy approach, but I felt once discovery was complete there was not nearly enough focus on actual strategy development. In my opinion, we ended up doing providing a market research project first and foremost (reporting on findings), rather than focusing on the analysis of said findings and actually developing an operational strategy. I'm not sure our team was actually equipped for the latter, so perhaps that's not necessarily a bad thing, but it felt like we what we said we were doing and what we were actually doing were two different things.
column43: Derene Allen - wonderful personality, capable, but a little too much of an abstract thinker for my taste.

column47: Our group was given the okay to go off course and execute an Operational Strategy project that was the first of its kind for Taproot. Given this new ground, I remain very surprised that we were not given more direct support/guidance from Taproot. I would think that the feedback loop during a new type of Taproot grant would be key to its success, but this felt very much like we were on our own, and I feel the project suffered a bit for it. I know our client was happy with the deliverables, but I'm shocked that Taproot never once wanted to meet with our entire team to go over processes and guidelines, and to gain insight into what worked and what didn't.

column41: I found the Taproot Blueprint to be a bit cumbersome. This was my first project and I tried to follow the outline as provided, but found the process distracting and overly laborious. I feel that the Blueprint should be a guideline, a benchmark, but not a mandate. The board of this nonprofit proved to be a key constituency in the overall success of the new logo. Next time around I will be better prepared to counsel the client on navigating the process of board buy-in. All in all, this was a very positive project and process.
column42: I would gladly work with the entire team again and hope I have an opportunity to do so.
column47: CSA is a most deserving client. They were so appreciative of our time and effort on their behalf. I would definitely recommend them for a future grant and I would love to work with them again.

I was surprised that Taproot did not provide more supplies - white boards for brainstorming sessions, negotiated contracts with copiers.  For all our time I did not think it was apprioriate for us also to pay for copies, etc.....

column40: Helping PCL clarify its program messaging to get more funding. They are doing important work for California.
column41: Falling off schedule. The client had some issues come up that made it difficult for them to follow-up with us. Fortunately, our team was comprised of experienced professionals who could work quickly to fill in the gaps.

column40: The most beneficial part was that the client did not try to micromanage the design. They were fantastic about describing the feel that they wanted in their piece, and gave me free reign--and it paid off for both of us. I love it, and they do too.
column41: It was frustrating and difficult to get content from both my Taproot team and our client team according to the schedule we agreed to--when the schedule would slip (i.e. copywriting taking 2 extra weeks, client feedback coming a week late), the time shortage fell in my lap--at one point I did ~25 hours of design in a matter of a few days and I would have loved to not felt so squeezed. Eventually I started pushing back, and that helped somewhat.

column40: A website is so important for nonprofits these days, so getting Options for Youth a dynamic web presences was very rewarding. That will certainly help their mission in the future.
column41: The paperwork at the beginning was pretty cumbersome. Also, the meetings tended to drag a little more than they probably should have.

column40: The most beneficial part of the project was just having the opportunity to work with a nonprofit (my regular job involves measuring financial performance of a large corporation).  It offered a nice change of perspective.
column41: The most frustrating part of the project for me was dealing with the fact that, as a nonprofit, their financial records were a bit scattered and I had a difficult time getting answers to certain questions.
column47: Overall it was a very good experience.  I wish I could have contributed much more to the project, but in this situation the limitations of their financial records and the difficulty in getting answers to questions necessary for an accurate representation of their finances left us with no option other than a basic, vanilla financial summary (which isn't necessarily a bad thing).  In any future projects I may do, I hope to take the initiative to help the clients with visual representation of whatever data/numbers they have rather than just the financial results.

column40: Contributing to a center for the arts that truly cares about the community and strives to interact with its supporters and admirers.
column41: Driving to the burbs for team meetings, which wasn't really that bad at all.  We did have trouble getting in touch with a few discovery interviews but still completed quite a few.
column42: Miah Armour, Roopa Shortt, Darcy Schuller, Gina Signorella

column40: For the client, I think the most beneficial part was being able to get a clearer positive understanding of their organization, which focused on the true value they deliver, and a clear understanding of how to relate that through key messages and marketing communications.  For me, I got to sharpen my skills at developing key messages for a new client that delivers services I think really help people who need them, and came away with a deeper grasp of the relationship between organizational defining an organization's values and developing their brand and messaging.
column41: When I joined the project (in progress), I thought it should have been much further along than it was and that the initial client research and groundwork were sketchy. Later on, I sensed a lack of focus at times and felt not all team members were pulling in the same direction. I think the Account Director provided gentle, discreet guidance behind the scenes that brought us back on track and led to good outcomes.
column47: I really enjoy doing pro bono through Taproot. Two suggestions (more related to my previous project than this one):  1. Help PMs and ADs learn how to spot a client or project problem more quickly and act to rectify the situation before time and effort are wasted.  2. Simplify and streamline some of the Taproot processes (e.g., the Blueprint) and let volunteers know they should be applied more flexibly, depending on the particular situation. They are presented too much as "one size for all."

column41: Personnel turnover on both sides made the process difficult and frustrating.  Our Taproot project manager had to leave for personal reasons, however I believe this wasn't much of a problem and the rest of the group stepped up to successfully take on her role.  But the loss of two key members of the CNI staff, including Exec. Director, totally left the project in limbo for too long.  And ultimately, I think the whole project became much less of a priority for the organization, at least in the short term.  The project has been closed but I don't there's a great feeling of accomplishment among the team that did the work.

column40: I thought our team worked really well together, and the participation from Chicago Commons was amazing.  Working with non-profits on a daily basis at work, it was refreshing to see the kind of commitment and passion Chicago Commons had for this project, their organization and the overall community they serve.
column41: The Chicago Commons team was (rightfully so) very particular about the way things were worded on the new site, and provided a majority of the content themselves.  While there was still a lot of copy written and edited by me, I at times felt like I was the "slacker" of our group - not having much to do/contribute.  I hope my teammates did not view me that way as well.

column47: I think the scope of the various strategy project is far too limited.
